High-spined lizard
Land.description1Russian: Could hunt almost all herbivorous dinosaurs in its ecosystem. An already bulky body, it was given an even more impressive appearance by the processes on the dorsal vertebrae, together forming a hump or a sail, which served either to scare away enemies and attract partners or for thermoregulation. Developed a speed of up to 40 km / h. More than a dozen skeletons up to 12.5 m long are known.
Land.description2Russian:
The Acrocantosaurus is a huge animal with a skull about 129 cm long, total body length reaching 11.5 meters (38 feet) with an estimated weight of 5.5 to 7 tons. The skull is similar in shape to the skull of Carcharodontosaurus and Allosaurus - low, with ornamentation on the upper surface. The neck is powerful, straight, the muzzle when walking was lowered approximately at an angle of 25 ° to the ground. The spinous processes reached 35 cm in height, forming a semblance of a low sail, which is why from the mid-1960s to the 1980s, it was classified as a spinosaurid. At the same time, unlike the dimetrodon sail, the spinous processes in sailing dinosaurs, for example, spinosaurus and uranosaurus, are very thick. For Acrocantosaurus, it is assumed that the high spinous processes are associated with the development of very powerful dorsal muscles that could support the hump, so the "sail" as such might not exist. The legs are relatively short, the front legs are also short, massive, with very large claws (especially on the first toe). Footprints, possibly belonging to an acrocantosaurus, were found in the Early Cretaceous sediments of the Paluxy, Texas, along with traces of sauropods, judging by the tracks, a predator was pursuing a herd.
  Acrocantosaurus could well attack an adult medium-sized sauropod, especially if the victim was sick or weakened, it is possible that acrocantosaurs could hunt in packs. Numerous remains of teeth, possibly belonging to the Acrocantosaurus, are known from Oklahoma, Arizona, Texas, Utah, and Maryland. It was the top predator of the so-called Cloverly Formation.

Land.description1Russian: Agustinia is a genus of lizard-like herbivorous dinosaurs from the group of sauropodomorphs that lived in the Lower Cretaceous era (about 116-100 million years ago), on the territory of present-day South America.
Land.description2Russian:
Fossils of this sauropodomorph have been found in the province of Neuquen, in the Lohan Cura Formation, Argentina. For the first time the species Agustinia ligabuei was classified in 1999 by the paleontologist Bonaparte.
     The most striking feature of this medium-sized sauropod is the set of plates on its back. They look like stegosaurus plates, but are turned sideways. They are rectangular in shape, but some are elongated into spikes pointing in different directions.   
 As for the structure of the body, some features indicate its belonging to diplodocides, while others indicate its relationship with titanosaurides. The classification is unclear at this point.

Land.description1Russian: Allosaurus was a real giant - its length from the tip of the nose to the tip of the tail was equal to the length of three modern heavy-duty vehicles combined. He was also a ferocious predator.
Land.description2Russian:
In order to support the weight of the body, the hind limbs of the allosaurs had to be very strong. First finger on the foot was turned backward, the other three - forward. Some scientists believe that this is the arrangement of the fingers helped Allosaurus, which had a colossal body mass, to move with great ease.
       The forelimbs of the Allosaurus were very small compared to its legs. Nevertheless, these limbs also had to be strong; they ended in three terrible curved claws, intended for tearing apart prey. The body of the Allosaurus was very massive and turned into a long and thick tail, tapering towards the end, which helped the Allazaurus to maintain balance when moving or in a fight with an enemy.
      Many dinosaur bones bear special marks called muscle attachment points. By studying these markings, scientists draw conclusions about how the muscles were attached to each dinosaur bone. Comparing their discoveries with data on modern animals, it is possible with a high degree of probability get an idea of the dinosaur lifestyle. In fact, this is how we learned about how powerful there were allosaurs.

Land.description1Russian: The only known incomplete skeleton was found by Guillermo Roger in February 1984, during an expedition led by the famous Argentine paleontologist José Bonaparte. This was the eighth expedition of the project Jurassic and Cretaceous Terrestrial Vertebrates of South America, which was supported by the National Geographic Society, begun in 1975.
Land.description2Russian:
The same expedition discovered an almost complete skeleton of a predatory Carnotaurus in the province of Neuquen, Argentina.
 Was described in 1991 as Amargasaurus cazaui, named after the locality The skeleton is quite complete and includes fragments of the temporal portion of the skull The skeleton is currently in the Bernardino Rivadavi Natural History Museum in Buenos Aires.
      The Amargasaurus was a small sauropod, estimated in 2004 to be 9 to 10 meters (30 to 33 feet) long and weighing about 2.6 tons. The neck consisted of 13 cervical vertebrae.
 The most striking feature of the skeleton was the extremely tall, upwardly protruding spinous processes on the neck and anterior thoracic vertebrae. The spinous processes were bifurcated along their entire length, forming two rows, they were round in cross-section and tapering towards their tips. The tallest spikes were located on the middle of the neck, reaching 60 centimeters (24 inches) in length. Amargasaurus walked on four limbs, the front limbs were shorter than the hind ones. All of its elephant-like legs had five toes, one of the toes on each limb bore a claw, possibly used for protection. As scientists suggest, perhaps the Amargasaurs could stand on their hind legs to pick leaves from the tops of trees or scare off enemies, as well as for protection, the dinosaur could use its thin whip-like tail.
 Amargasaurus had blunt teeth adapted for tearing leaves from branches, a relatively short neck suggests that the dinosaur ate vegetation in the lower tier: 0.8-2.7 meters above ground level.

Fused lizard
Land.description1Russian: It is sometimes described as a living tank because the whole body of the lizard was chained in an extremely durable armor. Ankylosaurus always could try to resist the attack even the most ferocious and hungry predators.
Land.description2Russian:
The body of the Ankylosaurus was undoubtedly quite massive. In addition, he had strong bone armor that covered the entire upper body and tail. This armor consisted of many small bone plates or plaques that had grown into the skin of the ankylosaurus. As additional protection in the center of each such growth there was a spike-like thickening. The growths were covered horny scales and are soldered (connected) to each other by long stripes, which is one of the reasons why this dinosaur is called ankylazaurus - a fused lizard. As you can probably guess, the armor was very heavy.
    Hard sharp spikes sticking out on the back made the ankylosaurus's armor even more impregnable, so that the only part of the body that was not protected from the attack of predators was its soft belly. Sometimes the enemy would try to knock the ankylosaurus onto its back and then attack the lizard in this vulnerable position.
     Generally speaking, the prospect of attacking an indestructible ankylosaurus should have deterred predators. Even the most ferocious carnivorous dinosaurs, like the Tyrannosaurus Rex, had to think carefully before deciding to attack him. As you can see in this illustration, the armored ankylosaurus could easily repel an even larger predator by striking with its tail, at the end of which there was a huge heavy growth. Such a blow could overturn a tyrannosaurus rex moving on two legs. Naturally, the position of the predator in this case was less stable than that of the four-legged ankylosaurus. After such a blow, the predator could hardly rise and was probably doomed to a long and painful death.

Land.description1Russian:
Leading 19th century paleontologist Othniel Charles Marsh, professor at Yale University, named the species Apatosaurus ajax in 1877, based on a spinal column  found in the vast Morrison Formation, east of the Rocky Mountains in Gunnison County, Colorado, USA.
 The name of the genus means misleading lizard, according to Marsh, the skeleton reached about 15 meters in length.
Land.description2Russian:
Apatosaurus reached 21-22.8 m (69-75 feet) in length and weighed up to 16-22 tons, it had a more massive build than the diplodocus. In 2013, bones were found in Oklahoma that were 11-30% larger than sample CM 3018, which suggests a mass of 33 tons. Like other sauropods, the cervical vertebrae were bifurcated; they carried spinous processes with a large bend in the middle, as a result of which the lizard had a wide and powerful neck. The vertebral formula for A. louisae consists of 15 cervical vertebrae, 10 dorsal, 5 pelvic and 82 caudal vertebrae. Neck length reached 7 meters (23 feet). The number of caudal vertebrae can vary even within a species. The cervical vertebrae of Apatosaurus and Brontosaurus were hollow and more powerful than those of Diplodocus, being the closest to Camarasaurus. The large neck was filled with an extensive air bag system to save weight. Apatosaurus had ten dorsal ribs on either side of the body, the ribs were very long compared to most other diplodocides, giving it an unusually deep chest. Apatosaurus, like its close relative, Supersaurus, has tall spinous processes of the spine that make up more than half the height of the individual bones of its vertebrae. As with other diplodocides, the tail ended in a whip-like structure at the tip. The limb bones were also very strong.
 The femurs of the Apatosaurus are very thick, the tibia and fibula are different from the thin bones of Diplodocus, but almost indistinguishable from the Camarasaurus. The fibula is longer and thinner than the tibia, the hind limbs were longer than the front. Apatosaurus had one large claw on each forelimb, a feature that is common to all sauropods close to the early Shunosaurus.
 The single hand claw of the bone (nail) is slightly curved and truncated at the anterior end. The phalanx formula is 2-1-1-1-1, which means that the limb has five fingers, and the innermost finger (phalanx) on the forelimb consists of two bones. The formula of the phalanges of the hind limbs is 3-4-5-3-2. The first three toes on each hind limb also had claws.

Land.description1Russian: The MPSC holotype R 2089 was discovered in a gypsum mine in 2008, and the fossil holotype was taken to the Placido Cidade Nuvens Museum of Paleontology for preparation and description.
Land.description2Russian:
Between 2008 and 2016, microscopic examinations of the tissues of the holotype were carried out using small bone samples. Also in 2016, the holotype was taken to the National Museum of Brazil, but on September 2, 2018, the museum burned down in a fire, but the area where the holotype was kept remained untouched. In 2020, the holotype was described as a new genus Aratasaurus. Only the right leg was collected, although more skeleton was probably present but not assembled.
     The holotype fossil consists of an incomplete right limb, including a partial femur, tibia, and lobe. The bones are similar to the Zuolong, a similar dinosaur from Late Jurassic China. Based on osteohistological studies, the Aratasaurus specimen is immature, approximately four years old at the time of death.

Land.description1Russian: At the end of the 20th century, South America became one of the largest suppliers of dinosaur fossils. And among them there are real giants, both carnivorous and herbivorous. The Latin name Argentinosaurus comes from the ancient Greek word for pangolin and the country of Argentina. Obviously, the Argentine Lizard got it from where he was found. It is considered one of the largest prehistoric reptiles.
Land.description2Russian:
The first remains of Argentinosaurus were discovered by the farmer Guillermo Heredia in the late 1980s on the territory of an ordinary farm Las Overas, located 8 kilometers from the small town of Plaza Wincul (province of Neuquen, Argentina). Now it is the territory of the Winkul formation, which is part of the larger Limai formation.
     The man reported the find to the staff of the Municipal Museum of Carmen Funes, and they removed the shin of an Argentinosaur from the ground. Then she was exhibited in the same museum. In the summer of 1989, a commission from the Argentine Museum of Natural Sciences, led by Jose Fernando Bonaparte, mined the fossil material in a field work funded by the National Geographic Society.
     The description of the species was published by the famous Argentine paleontologists José Fernando Bonaparte and Rodolfo Coria in 1993. The holotype specimen received the identification number MCF PVPH-1. In addition to it, Argentinosaurus owns an incomplete femur sample MLP-DP 46-VIII-21-3.

Land.description1Russian: Atrociraptor is a genus of dromaeosaurid theropod dinosaur from the Late Cretaceous (Maastrichtian stage) of Alberta, Canada.
Land.description2Russian:
The type (and only) specimen of Atrociraptor, holotype RTMP 95.166.1, was discovered by Wayne Marshall in 1995, in layers of the Horseshoe Canyon Formation also containing an Albertosaurus bonebed, near Drumheller. This bonebed is located at the top of Unit 4 of the Horseshoe Canyon Formation, which dates to about 68.5 million years ago. The only known specimen consists of parts of the upper and lower jaws—both premaxillae, a right maxilla, both dentaries—teeth and numerous small fragments. The skull appears to have been unusually short and tall. The teeth are relatively straight, but they emerge from the tooth sockets at an angle to the jaw line, resulting in a strongly raked row of teeth. A number of isolated teeth (previously referred to Saurornitholestes) have also been recovered from the Horseshoe Canyon Formation; they can be recognized by their unusually large serrations.
  In 2010 Gregory S. Paul estimated its length at two meters, its weight at fifteen kilogrammes. Atrociraptor differs from Bambiraptor and other velociraptorines in its more isodont dentition — the teeth have different sizes but the same form — and short deep snout. A skull opening, the maxillary fenestra, is relatively large and positioned right above another opening, the promaxillary fenestra, a condition not known from other species.
      Atrociraptor was by its describers assigned to the Velociraptorinae within a larger Dromaeosauridae. However, in 2009 Currie published a cladistic analysis showing Atrociraptor to be a member of the Saurornitholestinae.

Land.description1Russian: The fossil remains were discovered in the Gobi Desert and officially described by Russian paleontologist Sergei Kurzanov in 1981 as Avimimus portentosus, which means birdlike. Since no tail was found in the original find, Kurzanov erroneously concluded that the Avimim did not have a tail in his life, however, subsequent finds of the Japanese expedition containing the caudal vertebrae confirmed the presence of a tail. The second almost complete copy of Avimim was discovered in 1996 and described in 2000 by Japanese colleagues S. Suzuki and M. Watabe.
Land.description2Russian:
Avimim was a small bird-like dinosaur 1.5 m (5 ft) long. The skull was small compared to the body, although the brain and eyes were large. The size of the bones that surround and protect the brain are large. This is also consistent with the hypothesis that Avimimus had a proportionally large brain. The jaws of the avimimus were thought to form a parrot-like beak without teeth, and careful analysis of the anatomy of the holotype confirmed that the teeth were not preserved, although a series of jagged projections along the tip of the premaxillary bone were preserved.
  However, it was reported that subsequently discovered specimens retain small premaxillary teeth. The small teeth or possible lack of teeth in Avimimus suggests that it may have been a herbivore or omnivore.

Land.description1Russian: Bagualosaurus is a genus of sauropodomorph dinosaur from the Santa Maria Formation of Brazil, dating to around 230 million years ago in the Carnian of the Late Triassic. It includes one species, Bagualosaurus agudoensis.
Land.description2Russian: Bagualosaurus was a modest-sized basal sauropodomorph, measuring approximately 2.5 metres (8.2 ft) in length that, based on its teeth, was a herbivore. Features of its skull and dental structure are similar to later Norian sauropodomophs such as Pantydraco, Efraasia and Plateosaurus. However, its post-cranial skeleton resembles earlier forms. Likewise, it is somewhat smaller than Norian sauropodomorphs, yet significantly larger than other sauropodomorphs of its time, suggesting that it is transitional between the sauropodomorphs of its time and their later Norian descendants.

Land.description1Russian: Unsurprisingly, this British dinosaur received the nickname Clawed. The huge claws that grew on the fingers of his forelimbs were a mine almost as big as a human hand!
Land.description2Russian: For the first time, the remains of a baryonyx were found next to the fossilized bones of an iguanodon - another dinosaur with claws on opposing fingers. Scientists tried to understand: could it happen that these two lizards killed each other in a fight for food or territory? Considering the skeleton of the baryonyx, which experts collected from scattered pieces, one can confidently distinguish a number of characteristic features in the structure of its body. These features include, for example, an oblong skull sitting on a long neck.

Land.description1Russian: The fossilized bones were found in 1996, near Beipiao City, Liaoning Province, China. The new species was described in 1999 by Xu Xing and co-authors under the guise of Beipiaosaurus inexpectus - lizard from Beipiao.
Land.description2Russian:
Beipiaosaurus was 2.2 meters (7.3 feet) long. The skull had a toothless beak in front, the teeth were located in the back, near the cheeks. The body had a feather cover.
    In contrast to the more advanced therizinosaurids, which have four functional toes on their hind legs, the feet of the Beipyaosaurus still retain smaller inner toes, which indicates that therizinosaurids descended from a three-toed ancestor, whose fourth toe in descendants regained contact with the ground. This is in part consistent with the discovery of the ancestry of the Coelurosauria group.
    The head was large compared to other Therizinosaurs, with the length of the lower jaw being about the same as that of the femur. In 2003, the pygostyle, consisting of the last five fused vertebrae of the tail, was described in more detail. 
    Soft tissue imprints from a type B. inexpectus specimen showed that the body was covered with predominantly fluffy feather fibers, similar to those of Sinosauropteryx, but longer and oriented perpendicular to the arm. Xu et al., Who described this specimen, suggested that these fluffy feathers represent an intermediate stage between Sinosauropteryx and more advanced birds (Avialae). The tail was covered with feathers from four to seven centimeters long, composed of parallel filaments 1.5 millimeters wide. no trace of pennants or tail fan.
    Unique among the known theropods, Beipiaosaurus also possessed a secondary layer of much longer and simpler feathers that rose from the lower layer. These unique feathers (known as EBFFs, or elongated wide filamentous feathers) were first described by Xu et al. In 2009 based on a torso, head and neck specimen. Xu and his team also found EBFFs in the original B. inexpectus specimen, identified during further preparation.
    EBFFs differ from other types of feathers in that they are composed of a single unbranched strand. Most other primitive feathered dinosaurs had downy feathers, consisting of two or more filaments, branching from a common base or along a central shaft. The feathers of the Beipiaosaurus are also much longer than those of other dinosaurs, measuring about 100-150 millimeters (4-6 inches) in length, which is about half the length of the neck. Sinosauropteryx has the longest feathers only about 15% of the neck length.
     Beipiaosaurus also has unusually wide pimples, up to 3 mm wide in the type specimen. The widest Sinosauropteryx feathers are only 0.2 mm wide and only slightly wider in larger forms such as dilun. Also, where most of the primitive types of feathers have a circular cross section, they appear to be oval in shape.

Land.description1Russian: In 2011, workers discovered the remains of a dinosaur in tar sands in Alberta, Canada. Only the front part of the lizard has survived, from head to croup, but in excellent condition. In addition to the skeleton, the scientists found skin, spiked protective shields that covered the animal's back, and some soft tissue. Even a thin organic film has been preserved, which formed from the keratin layer covering the shell.
Land.description2Russian:
Scientists note that the borealopelta was larger than most modern mammals, which have a protective coloration. As you know, the largest herbivorous mammals living today - the elephant and the rhinoceros - do without camouflage at all, because predators rarely dare to hunt them.
    The remains of the borealopelta show a unique three-dimensional preservation. Several similar hadrosaurid mummies are known, but all of them are either shriveled or crushed by rocks.
      The sample of the borealopelta has been preserved almost completely due to being at the bottom of the reservoir. Externally, the lizard remained almost without significant changes and damage.
     The body of the borealopelta was covered with osteoderms on the back and sides.
      There were two long spikes on the shoulders. Borealopelta and Anchiornis are one of the few dinosaurs whose coloration has been restored. Nodosaurid was reddish brown in color with small contrasting protective patches.

Land.description1Russian: Brachiosaurus was one of the largest and heaviest dinosaurs that ever lived on Earth. At the same time, he was completely non-aggressive and entered into battle only when attacked by predators.
Land.description2Russian:
Like all sauropod dinosaurs, the Brachiosaurus was a four-legged animal with a small skull, long neck, large torso, long muscular tail, and slender, pillar-like limbs. Large air sacs associated with the lung system were present in the neck and trunk, entering the vertebrae and ribs through bone resorption, significantly reducing overall body density.
      The holotype specimen did not have a neck, but it was very long even by sauropod standards, as can be judged from the fossil remains of a closely related giraffatitan to brachiosaurus, whose neck consisted of thirty elongated cervical vertebrae. The neck was kept in a slight S-bend, with the lower and upper portions bent and a straight midsection.\n Brachiosaurus probably shared very elongated cervical ribs with the giraffatitan, which ran along the lower part of the neck, overlapping several anterior vertebrae. These bone rods were attached to the muscles of the neck at their ends, allowing these muscles to operate on the distal portions of the neck while being closer to the torso, lightening the distal portions of the neck.

Thunder lizard
Land.description1Russian: Brontosaurus is a genus of giant four-legged sauropod dinosaurs that includes three species. Although the type species, Brontosaurus excelsus, has long been considered one of the closely related Apatosaurus species, later research has shown that Brontosaurus is a genus separate from Apatosaurus. Brontosaurus and Apatosaurus are classified into the subfamily Apatosaurinae.
Land.description2Russian:
Brontosaurus had a long neck, an equally long tail, and a disproportionately small head. These calm giants are classified as herbivorous dinosaurs. They were very large, heavy and slow, and, moreover, did not have sharp teeth, so they died from the attacks of predatory dinosaurs.
     Several Brontosaurus nests were found, each containing five eggs. Scientists do not know how many clutches these lizards could make per year. Most likely, such a large lizard as brontosaurus laid eggs many times. Brontosaurus eggs were about 30 cm long and were covered with strong, rough shells. It is believed that the brontosaurus buried them in the ground. Scientists do not know how long the incubation could last.
     Huge long-necked brontosaurs lived in the late Jurassic period. At that time, a warm and humid climate prevailed on the continent that is now called North America. Along the swampy riverbanks, ginkgo trees and giant ferns, horsetails and huge conifers grew. All this succulent vegetation was an excellent food source for herbivorous dinosaurs. Brontosaurs kept along the banks of reservoirs and fed on various low-growing plants. Mostly they ate the vegetation covering the shores of lakes and rivers, and the leaves of trees.
     The orbits in the skull of the brontosaurus are displaced far back. The long and flat teeth at the front of the jaw were designed to pluck and collect plant matter in the mouth. In addition, the nostrils of the brontosaurus were located high enough, probably so that branches did not enter the nose during feeding. The huge brontosaurs were peaceful herbivorous dinosaurs. They ate succulent plants. Apatosaurus gnawed at the tops of trees, looking for succulent leaves, he did not have to, like predatory dinosaurs, track down prey and pursue it.
      Brontosaurs coexisted peacefully with their other relatives, for example, brachiosaurs. Like other large herbivores, brontosaurs were very easy prey for predatory animals that lived in the Jurassic period. He had practically no weapons for self-defense - he did not differ in speed, he did not have sharp teeth. The most reliable weapon of a brontosaurus is a very long and mobile tail tapering towards the end. With them, the brontosaurus inflicted very strong blows on the enemy. On the inside of the foot of the brontosaurus there was a large claw, which also served as a weapon.
     Brontosaurus was not the largest dinosaur, but against the general background it still stood out for its enormous size and mass. He had a small head. Some researchers believe that brontosaurus' feet had special pads that prevented foot injury. Probably, brontosaurs could overcome reservoirs, rowing only with their forelimbs, and the body was kept on the water.

Land.description1Russian: Carcharodontosaurus is a giant carnivorous dinosaur from Africa that lived in the Cretaceous period 100-94 million years ago in the territory of modern Africa.
Land.description2Russian:
The first two teeth were discovered in Algeria in 1924. Charles Depere and Savornin assigned them to the genus Megalosaurus saharicus in 1925, but in 1927 they renamed them Dryptosaurus saharicus. In 1914, scattered bones of a carnivorous dinosaur were discovered in the Baharij Formation of Egypt, consisting of a fragment of a skull, teeth, several vertebrae and a hind thigh bone. These teeth were identical to the specimens described by Depere and strongly resembled shark teeth, on this basis, Ernst Stromer in 1931 described these remains as Carcharodontosaurus saharicus - a lizard with shark teeth. Unfortunately, these samples were lost during the Second World War, in 1944.
      New fossils were discovered by paleontologist Paul Sereno in 1995, in the Kem-Kem Formation, Morocco, near the Algerian border, and consisted of an incomplete skull (SGM-Din 1 sample). In 2007, Steven Brusat and Paul Sereno designated it as a neotype, and in the same year they described a new species, Carcharodontosaurus iguidensis, based on a jawbone with teeth from Niger (sample MNN IGU2).
     In 2010, Gregory Paul proposed to rename the Giganotosaurus to C. carolinii. However, this decision was not supported. 
      In the 1960s, a huge number of various fragments of Cretaceous theropods were attributed to Carcharodontosaurus, without sufficient signs for this. It is possible that several carcharodontosaurids lived at the same time as C. saharicus, so many researchers limit the specimens of this species.
      The skull is poorly known, but resembled that of the Giganotosaurus, the teeth were jagged and reached 20 cm in length. In 1996, Paul Sereno estimated the possible length of the skull at 1.6 meters. Probably, Carcharodontosaurus could hunt the largest sauropods - titanosaurs, whose bones were found in the same deposits. As with the Giganotosaurus, there is no evidence of gregarious behavior for the Carcharodontosaurus. Carcharodontosaurus were the dominant carnivorous predators in Africa, with an estimated body size of 10 to 12.8 meters in length and 7.8 tonnes in weight.

Land.description1Russian: Carnotaurus is a genus of carnivorous dinosaurs from the Abelisaurid family that lived during the Upper Cretaceous period (83.6-66.0 million years ago). Described by J. Bonaparte in 1985, the remains were found in the deposits of Gorro Frigio, Chubut province (Argentina). Known for its complete skeleton with skin imprints.
Land.description2Russian:
Thanks to the study of the Carnotaurus, the Abelisaurids were separated into a separate family. The dinosaur had a very short and tall skull, with two horn-like, flattened outgrowths above the eyes. The hind limbs are rather long and slender, while the forelimbs are extremely reduced (even less than in the tyrannosaurus), but they retained four fingers. The eyes are very small, perhaps the sense of smell played an important role in orientation. The teeth are numerous and well suited for cutting off pieces of meat, but not large, the lower jaw is weak. The skull had a pronounced kineticism (the joints between the bones are mobile) - this made it possible to swallow whole large pieces of meat or small animals. For example, the front of the skull could be slightly raised - like in birds. The bite was quick, but not very strong. Skin imprints show conical and disc-shaped, non-overlapping scales covering the entire body.
       Probably, he hunted mainly small animals like ornithopods and dromaeosaurids, but at times he could attack larger animals like sauropods. The length of the only known specimen reached from 7.5 to 9 meters, weight, according to various estimates, from 1.5 to 2.1 tons. Its age was originally considered Middle Cretaceous, but now it is known that Carnotaurus lived at the end of the Cretaceous (Campanian - Maastrichtian).

Land.description1Russian: Ceratosaurus was a large bipedal dinosaur with powerful hind limbs and reduced forelimbs. The length of the skeleton of the largest specimen of ceratosaurus found is estimated at approximately 7 m.The weight, according to various estimates, varies greatly: from 275 to 980 kg for different specimens.
Land.description2Russian:
A distinctive feature of the anatomy of a ceratosaurus was a raised horn on the nasal bones of the skull, from which the lizard got its name, as well as two horn protrusions above the eyes. More than half of the teeth in the upper jaw were very long and strong; the teeth of the lower jaw were smaller and less strong. Along the midline of the back, the skin of the ceratosaurs was covered with a number of osteoderms.
    Ceratosaurs lived near rivers, lakes and swamps, often entering the water and hunting aquatic animals: fish, crocodilomorphs and turtles. However, they could diversify their diet with the meat of larger terrestrial herbivores, while participating in the competition with the Allosaurus.
       The skull was quite large in proportion to the rest of its body. It measures 55 cm (22 in) in length in the C. nasicornis holotype, measured from the tip of the snout to the occipital condyle, which connects to the first cervical vertebra. The width of this skull is difficult to reconstruct, as it is heavily distorted, and Gilmore's 1920 reconstruction was later found to be too wide. The fairly complete skull of specimen MWC 1 was estimated to have been 60 cm (24 in) in length and 16 cm (6.3 in) in width; this skull was somewhat more elongated than that of the holotype. The back of the skull was more lightly built than in some other larger theropods due to extensive skull openings, yet the jaws were deep to support the proportionally large teeth. The lacrimal bone formed not only the back margin of the antorbital fenestra, a large opening between eye and bony nostril, but also part of its upper margin, unlike in members of the related Abelisauridae. The quadrate bone, which was connected to the lower jaw at its bottom end to form the jaw joint, was inclined so that the jaw joint was displaced backwards in relation to the occipital condyle. This also led to a broadening of the base of the lateral temporal fenestra, a large opening behind the eyes.

Land.description1Russian: The horned dinosaur Chasmosaurus from the late Cretaceous formation of Alberta, Dinosaur Park, is known from numerous skulls and skeletons, but even a century after its description, the taxonomy of the genus remains controversial. Currently, two main species are recognized: Chasmosaurus belli and C. russelli, three other species that have eventually been isolated into their own genera. In 2015, Nicholas Longreach of Yale University examined the skull of a Hasmosaurus from the Peabody Museum of Natural History, copy of YPM 2016.
Land.description2Russian:
The Hasmosaurus was a member of a diverse group of Hasmosaurines, differing in the individual shape of the cranial frill. In 2010, Gregory Paul estimated its length at 4.8 meters and weight at 2 tons. Like many other ceratopsians, the Hasmosaurus had three horns - one on the nose and two on the forehead. In both species these horns were rather short, but in C. russelli the brow horns were longer and more curved backward. The fringe of the Hasmosaurus is very elongated and widened strongly at the top. The bony collar had very large triangular holes, while other ceratopsians had oval holes. 
      In 2010, Phillip Curry, chair of the Department of Paleobiology in the Department of Biological Sciences, found a remarkable specimen of a small Hasmosaurus. On a high steep slope, he noticed a piece of skull protruding from the ground, at first he was sure that it was a tortoise shell, but after a day of excavation work, the significance of the find was confirmed, a whole skeleton was found. It took three more years of painstaking work before it could be demonstrated to the whole world. The skeleton was completely intact except for the forelimbs, which were probably eroded by rainstorms several thousand years ago. This is one of the finest specimens ever found.

Land.description1Russian: Several scattered remains of coelophysis were first found in 1881. Then, in 1947, a large number of remains were found in New Mexico; the preservation of some of the skeletons was amazing: neither before nor after that it was possible to find such a well-preserved remains of dinosaurs.
Land.description2Russian:
For dinosaurs, coelophysis was not large - only about 3 meters long, with most of this length falling on the neck and tail. Although they were not giants, they were still dangerous predators: when attacking a prey, they used their front limbs.    
Cannibals!
   Coelophysis was one of the first dinosaurs to appear on Earth and was one of the first to be thoroughly studied. The most startling discovery was that coelophysis fed on members of their own species. Scientists were amazed to find the bones of a coelophysis cub inside the chest of an adult.

Land.description1Russian: Compsognathus is a small carnivorous dinosaur that lived in Europe in the Late Jurassic period 152-145 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
Judging by the skeletons found, the length reached 60-100 cm, the largest individuals - 140 cm. The weight of the predator, taking into account its size and light bones, was about 2.5 kg. 
      Compsognathus was a small bipedal theropod. The long, narrow head of the animal was set on a long, curved neck. The skull and lower jaw were thin and slender, which meant they were rather fragile. The jaws contained small and sharp teeth. The neck, apparently, was quite mobile and allowed him to deftly rotate his head in all directions, which, perhaps, helped him to grab prey. 
      Compsognathus had long hind legs and an even longer tail, which he used to balance while moving. On the forelimbs, there were three fingers with sharp claws, with which it was possible to grab prey. The thin skull was narrow and long, ending in a wedge-shaped muzzle. The skull had five different openings, the largest of which were the orbits of the eye.

Land.description1Russian: Corytosaurus is classified as a duck-billed dinosaur in the lambeosaurine subfamily. It is related to other dinosaurs such as Hypacrosaurus, Lambeosaurus, and Olorotitan, all of which (with the exception of Olorotitan) have similar skulls and crests. However, recent research has shown that Olorotitan is the closest relative of Corytosaurus, although it does not share as many skull features with Corytosaurus as other lambeosaurines.
Land.description2Russian:
Corytosaurus weighed up to 4 tons and reached about 10 meters in length from nose to end of tail. Like other duck-billed dinosaurs, it had a toothless beak. In the mouth were dental batteries made up of hundreds of small, joined teeth. They were used to chew plant foods and were continually replaced.
     More than 20 skulls of this dinosaur have been found. Like other lambeosaurs, this animal had a high bony ridge on its skull containing elongated nasal passages. They formed a complex respiratory system of air pockets and sinuses inside the ridge. 
      Any sound made passed through this system, due to which, most likely, it was amplified. Scientists believe that Corytosaurus could make loud, low-frequency sounds.
      These sounds could be used to warn of the danger of other corytosaurs. 
 Once, because of the membranes on the front and hind limbs, Corytosaurus was believed to have lived in water. However, it was later discovered that the membranes are actually the so-called cushioning pads that are found in many modern mammals.

Land.description1Russian: Cryolophosaurus is a predatory theropod from Antarctica, lived in the Early Jurassic period 194-188 million years ago
Land.description2Russian:
In 1991, Ohio State University geologist David Elliot, while excavating Mount Kerkpatrick (part of the Mid-Antarctic Ridge) near Birdmore Glacier, came across fossilized bones in a rock at an altitude of 4,000 meters (13,000 feet) and about 640 km (400 miles) from the South poles. Eliot notified William Hammer of this, whose team, over three weeks, extracted 2,300 kg of fossilized rock containing about a hundred bones. The fossils were officially described in 1994 by William Hammer and William Hickerson as Cryolophosaurus ellioti, a frozen lizard with a crest. In 2003, a new expedition was organized and new remains were found 30 meters from the old excavations, which consisted of individual vertebrae and scattered animal bones, presumably 6 meters (20 feet) long.
    The most interesting find was a badly damaged, 65-cm skull with a unique transverse ridge, because of this ridge it was informally called Elvissaur, with an allusion to Elvis Presley's hair. The specimen (sample FMNH PR1821) consists of an incomplete skull, nine teeth, individual vertebrae and hind limb bones.
   In 1999, the size of the Cryolophosaurus was estimated to be approximately 6-7 meters. In 2007, a study by Nathan Smith, William Hammer and Philip Curry estimated its size to be 6.5 meters in length and 465 kg in weight. It was one of the first large predators in its ecosystem, along with Dilophosaurus, it is known from the deposits of the Early Jurassic, which sheds light on the evolution of early theropods. In a 2012 publication, Matthew Carrano describes similarities to the more advanced Chinese Sinosaur. Along with the remains of Cryolophosaurus, fossilized bones of large prozauropods, pterosaurs, and tritylodont synapsids were found.

Land.description1Russian: Daemonosaurus is a genus of lizard-like dinosaurs from the group of theropods that lived in the late Triassic period (205 million years ago) in the modern United States. The fossils were found in the Chinle Geologic Formation in the Ghost Ranch quarry in New Mexico.
Land.description2Russian:
Based on the size of the head and the proportions of related theropods, Hans-Dieter Süs suggested that the dinosaur was approximately 1.5 meters long. According to other sources, its length could reach 220 centimeters, height - 70 centimeters, and weight - 25 kilograms.
    The skull differs from other Triassic theropods: they had a short mouth with a broad premaxillary bone and upper jaw. The skull reached a length of 14 cm. The upper jaw was longer than the lower one and had large, backward-curved teeth. The lower jaw was smaller, but there were very sharp teeth on it.
    The most ancient theropod dinosaurs, such as Herrerasaurus and Stavricosaurus, are known from Argentina and Brazil. Nevertheless, the evolutionary diversification of this group from the Triassic-Jurassic is still poorly understood due to the rare fossil record near this boundary. Based on comprehensive phylogenetic analysis, demonosaurus is more closely associated with coelophysis and Tawa hallae of the same age, such as coelophysis and Tawa hallae, than with Herrerazaurids and Eoraptor. The various features of the demonosaur skull, including the unique arrangement of the mandibular and premaxillary teeth, and the significantly enlarged premaxillary and anterior maxilla, clearly show the differences in skull shape among theropod dinosaurs shortly before the end of the Triassic.

Land.description2Russian: Diabloceratops was medium in size and measured approximately 5.5 m (18 ft) in length. The skull had a wide nose as well as two superciliary horns. On the top of the bony collar were two large spines, reminiscent of those of the Achelosaurus.

Land.description1Russian: Dicraeosaurus is a genus of small sauropods of the late Jurassic era that lived in Africa about 150 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
This dinosaur was discovered during the German East African paleontological expedition of 1909-1913. In 1909-1910, Werner Janensch, together with his assistant Isa Salim, discovered the extensive occurrence of bone remains of sauropods in the Tendaguru Formation, in colonial East Germany (now Tanzania). The material found belonged to several animals, both adults and young. In 1914, Janensch described this find as Dicraeosaurus hansemanni. The name of the genus comes from the ancient Greek word dikraios two-headed, referring to the bifurcated chevrons of the cervical vertebrae. The species is named after pathologist David Paul von Hanssemann.
    The skeleton in Berlin reaches a length of 13.2 meters. Weight estimates have historically varied widely from 3.3 to 12.8 tonnes. In 2010, Gregory S. Paul estimated the length of the dikreosaurus at 14 meters and weight at 5 tons. A distinctive feature is that the bases of the middle and posterior cervical vertebrae are directed obliquely to the anterior vertebrae. The cervical vertebrae also have a unique bony keel on the anterior half of their underside. It is generally assumed that the vertical mobility of the dicreosaurus neck was very small. The shape of the cervical vertebrae and their teeth makes it impossible to raise the head above shoulder height. Kent Stevens in 2002 illustrated the spine in a neutral position, where the head was in a lowered state. Dycreosaurus apparently ate low vegetation or raised itself on its hind legs. However, the orientation of the front part of the body is also determined by the length of the front legs - they were very short, reaching only 64% of the length of the hind legs, which is one of the lowest values in all sauropods. However, this value becomes unreliable due to the fact that the reconstruction itself is composite, and the holotype did not retain the forelimbs. Dycryosaurids are also known from Argentina, such as the Jurassic Brachytrachelopan mesai, the Early Cretaceous Amargasaurus cazaui, and the recently described Chinese Lingwulong shenqi.

Land.description1Russian: Dilophosaurus has a very interesting head shape - it has a double bone crest on it. Dilophosaurus was a medium-sized, but fierce and ugly-looking predator that lived in some regions of the continent, which is now called North America.
Land.description2Russian:
In 1942, when in northern Arizona (United States of America), the remains of a previously unknown species of dinosaurs, the entire scientific world was excited. The remains were found by a group of paleontologists from the University of California, led by a Navajo Indian named Jess Williams.
     When scientists began excavations at the place indicated by the guide, after a while they unearthed three skeletons. One skeleton, reaching almost 6 m in length, was almost intact, but it did not have a skull, so no one could tell how looked like a dinosaur head. The other two skeletons were a mass of scattered parts, and many bones crumbled to dust over millions of years. Scientists could not tell which species dinosaurs could have belonged to the found remains.
    The American paleontologist Samuel P. Wells worked hard to put the bones together, but he made one great mistake: he decided that these remains belonged to the Megalosaurus. Perhaps he came to this conclusion because the dinosaur skull was missing, and some of the bones of Dilophosaurus and Megalosaurus are indeed similar (with the exception of the skull).
    Then, many years later, Wells found another similar skeleton, but this time in much better condition and with a complete skull topped with a double crest, which is the main distinguishing feature of Dilophosaurus. And then Wells realized that these remains did not belong to the Megalosaurus, but to a completely different species of fossil lizards.
     Later, in 1970, Wells gave this species the very name by which it is known to us today - Dilophosaurus, a lizard with two crests. The name itself was given to Dilophosaurus thanks to the double bone crest crowning its head.

Land.description1Russian: Dimetrodon is a genus of fossil carnivorous reptiles of the pelicosaur order. Evolutionarily closer to mammals than to true reptiles. They had an amazing sail.
Land.description2Russian:
Dimetrodon had a fairly large head with strong jaws dotted with sharp teeth. He was probably an active hunter: he hunted amphibians, reptiles and fish. With its front teeth, Dimetrodon held the victim and tore it apart. The back teeth were bent back, with their help, the animal tore apart small creatures and chewed large pieces of meat. The body of the Dimetrodon was barrel-shaped.
      The most striking feature of Dimetrodon is a sail made of skin stretched over the outgrowths of the dorsal vertebrae. Similar sails developed in various prehistoric animals (amphibians platihistrix, edaphosaurus and secodontosaurus pelicosaurs, spinosaurus dinosaur) and served as temperature regulators. According to other versions, the sail was used in mating games, served as camouflage among the vertical stems of plants or as a real sail when swimming. Sail developed gradually during life, there are known findings of young individuals of Dimetrodon with low spinous processes.
     Juveniles, apparently, lived in thickets along the banks of water bodies, like adults. Nevertheless, the image of Dimetrodon in popular books on the background of the desert seems unrealistic - not being a reptile, he could not survive in a hot dry area.

Land.description1Russian: The first fossilized diplodocus vertebrae were found by Benjamin Moge and Samuel Williston in 1877 near Canon City, Colorado, USA. The following year, 1878, Othniel Charles Marsh, a professor of vertebrate paleontology at Yale University, described them as Diplodocus longus (YPM 1920 holotype). The middle part of the tail contained chevrons of the vertebrae of an unusual shape, in the form of double beams, from which the diplodocus got its name.
Land.description2Russian:
It was one of the true giants of the late Jurassic period. According to the calculations of the researcher David Gillette, carried out in 1991, the size of the diplodocus could reach 54 meters in length and weigh 113 tons. Such estimates of the sizes turned out to be incorrect due to the incorrectly indicated number of vertebrae. According to modern estimates, the real size of the giant turned out to be much smaller. Diplodocus reached an average length of 27 meters, according to scientists, the size of the largest individuals could reach 35 meters. Most of them were on the neck and tail. According to some estimates, the weight of the diplodocus was 10–20 tons, and according to others, 20–80 tons. It is possible that there were dinosaurs larger than the diplodocus, for example, the supersaurus. However, their skeletons were not found entirely, but only in fragments.
    The neck and tail bones of the diplodocus were hollow. The neck consisted of 15 vertebrae, possibly filled with communicating air sacs. The diplodocus's tail was very long and consisted of 80 vertebrae, nearly double that of some other sauropods. The huge tail performed important functions: it may have served as an excellent defense weapon , and also served as a counterweight for the long neck. The middle part of the tail vertebrae has an unusual shape with double processes, which gave the diplodocus its name. The outgrowths could play the role of supporting the tail, and could also provide protection for blood vessels from compression.
    The head was small compared to the size of the animal. The skull had an unpaired nasal opening, located not at the tip of the muzzle, but in the upper part of the head in front of the eyes. Narrow scapula-shaped teeth were found only in the front of the mouth. The limbs of the diplodocus were five-toed, with short massive claws on the inner toes. The front legs are much shorter than the hind legs. Was one of the largest dinosaurs.

Land.description1Russian: A small bipedal herbivorous dinosaur with long hind limbs. With a length of 3 meters and a height of 1.7 meters, the Dryosaurus weighed 90 kilograms. Dryosaurs had huge eyes. They had long, thin legs with three toes, much shorter arms with five long toes.
Land.description2Russian:
Parts of the skeleton were found in the states of Colorado and Wyoming (USA), as well as in Tanzania. Dryosaurs lived in North America about 154 million years ago. An expedition led by German scientist Werner Janensch) discovered many dryosaur skeletons in Tanzania.
    Driosaurus received its name in 1894 from paleontologists at Yale University named after Goughoniel Charles Marsh.

Land.description1Russian: The fossils were discovered in 1991 by paleontologist Ricardo Martinez during excavations in Ischigualasto National Park, in the province of San Juan, Argentina.
Land.description2Russian:
It took an entire year to retrieve the holotype (sample PVSJ 512), which was then sent to the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, where the fossil was first exhibited, and then returned to the Museum of Natural Sciences, San Juan, Argentina. 
    In 1993, the genus was described by paleontologist Paul Sereno as Eoraptor lunensis - early robber, the name of the species lunensis is a reference to its place of discovery - Valle de la Luna, which means Valley of the Moon in Spanish.
    The eoraptor was about 1 meter (3.3 feet) long and weighed about 10 kg, and it had five fingers on its forelimbs, three of which, the longest, ended in large claws. The body was carried upright on its hind legs, and its front legs were half as long as the hind legs. The premaxillary bone had 4 teeth, another 18 were located in the upper jaw, Herrerasaurus had a similar pattern of teeth, on this basis it was suggested that these lizards either descended from omnivorous forms or were omnivores themselves. Eoraptor and Herrerasaurus are basal theropod forms and are at the earliest stage of their evolution.

Land.description1Russian: Erlikosaurus was a Therizinosaurus - a strange group of theropods that ate vegetation instead of meat. In addition, like the ornithischian dinosaurs, their jaws had a wide, rounded bony beak useful for plucking plants.
Land.description2Russian: Behind the beak, at some distance, there were 23 small straight teeth with notches located on both sides in the upper jaw. There were more mandibular teeth - 31 teeth. There were a total of one hundred and eight teeth. The skull is 25 centimeters long. Erlikosaurus had exceptionally long, slender claws on the limbs, up to 10 centimeters long, the purpose of which is not clear, Gregory Paul suggested that they were used for self-defense. This genus is known only from very fragmentary material, which has become a problem in determining the size of Erlicosaurus, especially in the absence of a spinal column in the holotype. In 2010, Gregory S. Paul gave an estimate of the length at 4.5 meters and weighing half a ton.

Like a chicken
Land.description1Russian: It is often referred to as the ostrich-like dinosaur; but it was much larger than the modern ostrich. Judging by the skeleton, the Gamimim was undoubtedly an unsurpassed runner, as evidenced by his mine thin but strong legs and minded, narrow foot bones.
Land.description2Russian:
There are a number of characteristics that make Gallimimus easy to distinguish from other dinosaurs. First, his hind legs were long and thin, which allowed him to take unusually wide strides. If you ever saw a running ostrich, you can clearly imagine how fast the gallimimus could run. The long legs of the Gallimimus ended in elongated feet, and this further convinced scientists that the Gallimimus could develop fantastic speed.
    Thus, in most cases, this fossil sprinter could get away from any predator that attacked it, literally in a few moments leaving the attacker far behind. Undoubtedly, this speed was useful when fishing various small prey, such as the dragonfly pictured below. In addition to dragonflies, gallimimus probably ate mainly leaves and berries, as well as lizards and shrews, if he managed to catch them.
    The Gallimimus beak was toothless. Therefore, he probably ate food that was small and soft enough that he could swallow it without chewing. His diet could include the eggs of other dinosaurs - he could open them with his sharp beak, as well as plants, lizards, insects and other small animals. It is possible that the Gallimimus used his claws to dig in the ground, looking for tasty worms and edible roots; he could also claw at small prey.
    One thing is certain: the Gallimim found enough food to provide himself with the energy he needed to run fast.

Late Cretaceous period

Giant lizard
Land.description1Russian: Giganotosaurus is a large carnivorous Upper Cretaceous dinosaur from the carcharodontosaurid family of the allosauroid superfamily. Described by the Argentine paleontologist Rodolfo Coria in 1995 on the basis of an almost complete skeleton of the Cenomanian stage (99.6-93.5 million years ago) from the Candeleros Formation (Rio Limay) near the province of Neuquen (Argentina). In terms of body length (the holotype is 12.2-12.5 m, the largest known specimen is ≈13.2 m) it belongs to the largest representatives of theropods, being second in size, probably, only to the Spinosaurus.
Land.description2Russian:
The femur and tibia are approximately equal in length. This means that the Giganotosaurus was not a frequent running animal. Since his main prey were large sauropods such as titanosaurs, he did not need high speed for hunting. It weighed about 7-8 tons, although there are estimates that indicate the mass of the largest known specimen of Giganotosaurus at as much as 13.8 tons. The skull of the Giganotosaurus differed from the skull of the Carcharodontosaurus primarily in its elongation. The preorbital fenestra was longer, and the lateral temporal fenestra was wider. The ornamentation of the skull is also developed - ridges on the nasal bones, above the eyes. This increased the strength of the skull and reduced its vulnerability in a fight. The physique of the Giganotosaurus is also somewhat more massive than the Carcharodontosaurus. Otherwise, these animals are quite similar to each other. It should be noted that, unlike tyrannosaurus, carcharodontosaurids did not have sufficiently developed binocular vision, their brains were smaller in volume, their physique was somewhat lighter, and their teeth were better suited for cutting off pieces of flesh. Thus, this group of theropods had traits suggesting a slightly different lifestyle compared to tyrannosaurs.
    Giganotosaurus had one of the longest skulls of any known theropod. The calculated size of the skull of the holotype is 1.8 m, the second specimen is 2 m, which is 30-50 cm larger than the largest skull of a Tyrannosaurus (the largest of the known skulls of a Tyrannosaurus is about 1.5 m in length, although at the same time slightly higher). Although, on the other hand, there is an opinion based on a comparison with other carcharodontosaurids that in reality the skulls of giganotosaurs were somewhat shorter - up to 1.6 m in the holotype.
     Giganotosaurus, Carcharodontosaurus and Tyrannosaurus were the largest terrestrial carnivorous dinosaurs known to science. Studies conducted in 1999 at the University of North Carolina (USA) showed that Giganotosaurus and Tyrannosaurus had a metabolic form characteristic of warm-blooded animals.

Crowned dragon
Land.description1Russian: This dinosaur was discovered in the Jungaria region, China, during a joint expedition by scientists from the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology and George Washington University. In 2006, the species was described by Xu Xing under the guise of Guanlong wucaii - a dragon with a crown, the name was given because of the unique bony outgrowth on the top of the skull.
Land.description2Russian:
The age of the find is about 160 million years, which is 92 million years earlier than the appearance of its more famous relatives, such as Tyrannosaurus. It is one of the most ancient representatives of the tyrannosauroid superfamily. Discovered by an expedition of paleontologists from the George Washington University in 2000 and described in 2006 as a new species and genus.
    The length is about 3 meters. Found two skeletons. This bipedal theropod shares many similarities with the Tyrannosaurus rex descendants of its relatives, and also had some unusual features such as a large crest on its head. Unlike later tyrannosaurs, the guanlong had three long toes on its forelimbs. In this he resembles his close relative Dilong, and like whom he may have had a plumage of primitive feathers. Lived on the territory of the modern Gobi Desert.

Land.description1Russian: Hadrosaurus is the first genus of duck-billed dinosaurs to be described, as well as the first reconstructed dinosaur from the United States of America.
Land.description2Russian:
In 1858, few people in the American Wild West heard the word dinosaur, which was first spoken by British professor Richard Owen 17 years ago. However, one of the members of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia, William Parker Folke, was not only familiar with the word, but also became famous for the discovery of the first dinosaur skeleton on the territory of the North American continent. Several dinosaur sculptures have already existed in Sydenham's English Park since 1854, they were recreated from several scattered bones and teeth discovered several decades earlier and had little in common with the creatures they depicted.
     The H. foulkii holotype (ANSP 10005) was found in marine sediments of the Woodbury Formation, suggesting that the animal probably drowned in a river and was then covered in sediment in the Cretaceous sea. However, some of the paleontologists of the time believed that hadrosaurs were aquatic animals and in early depictions they were often depicted next to bodies of water and with membranes between the fingers, like animals moving in an aquatic environment. The first to declare this way of life was Joseph Leidy, who suggested that the hadrosaurus was completely aquatic, despite the fact that he walked on two legs (Leidy, 1858). Quite strange, considering that all known aquatic animals are quadrupedals. After the discovery of the first hadrosaur skull, Edward Cope also believed that hadrosaurs were aquatic, based on their duck beak and weak teeth. Cope suggested that the only food they could eat were aquatic plants and algae (Cope, 1883). One of these arguments was refuted by Richard Lull and Nelda Wright, who showed that hadrosaur teeth were located in dental batteries and were constantly being replaced. Thus, hadrosaurs had jaws that functioned like a grinder, allowing them to grind hard plant material.

Land.description1Russian: The first few remains, including a destroyed skull, were found in 1958 by Alfred Sherwood Romer during a Harvard Paleontological Expedition in Ischigualasto National Park, in northwestern Argentina, in the province of San Juan.
Land.description2Russian:
Herrerasaurus has a narrow and long skull that lacks nearly all the specializations that characterize later theropods. The lizard had five pairs of holes in the skull, two of which were eye and nasal. Between the eyes and nostrils, there were two preorbital foramina and a pair of tiny, 1 cm long, narrow promaxillary foramina, all of which could significantly reduce the weight of the skull. The flexible connection in the lower jaw made it possible to move it back and forth and widen the bite. This specialization is unusual in dinosaurs, but developed independently in some lizards.
    The jaws were armed with large, serrated teeth for tearing meat. The neck was slender and flexible. The front legs of the Herrerasaurus are relatively short - less than half the length of the hind legs, but the hand was long. Her first two toes and thumb had curved and sharp claws for grabbing prey, while her fourth and fifth toes were just short stubs without claws. Strong hind legs with short thighs and long tsops for an extremely fast runner. The partially taut tail, ideal for balancing, also indirectly indicated fitness for running.

Different toothed lizard
Land.description1Russian: The first fossils were discovered during an Anglo-South African expedition in 1961-1962, at an altitude of about 1,890 meters (6,201 feet), in the Cape Province of South Africa. Sample (SAM-PK-K337) consists of skull fragments from one individual. In 1962, paleontologists Alfred Walter Crompton, from South Africa and Alan Harig, from the United Kingdom, described the species as Heterodontosaurus tucki, a different toothed lizard. The preparation of the sample and the release of the bone from the matrix took a very long time, since they were covered with a thin glandular layer containing hematite. This was only possible with a diamond saw.
Land.description2Russian:
In 2005, paleontologist Billy de Klerk found a new skeleton of a heterodontosaurus in the area of Grahamstown, South Africa. Even though the specimen was in excellent condition, the skeleton was too small and fragile, and there was too much fossilized rock around it to allow paleontologists to get a proper view of its anatomy. To shed light on the sample, university scientists spent five days at the European Synchrotron Source Radiation Facility (ESRF) in Grenoble, France, scanning the skeleton of a small dinosaur. The unique combination of powerful energy and a wide spectrum of X-rays allows the detection of fossilized bones in the surrounding rock, which has a similar density.
    Although it was a small dinosaur, Heterodontosaurus was one of the largest members of its family, reaching from 1.18 m (3.9 ft) to 1.75 m (5.7 ft) in length and weighing 2 to 10 kg (4, 4 and 22.0 lbs). The five-toed forelimbs were long and well developed, while the hindlimbs had only four toes. The skull was elongated and narrow, the front of the jaws ended in a horny beak and had three types of teeth, in the upper jaw they were small, such as incisors, which were accompanied by long canine teeth, and chisel-like teeth stood along the cheeks. Despite its large canine teeth, the heterodontosaurus was a herbivorous or omnivorous animal. Heterodontosaurids are considered one of the most primitive, or basal groups of ornithischian dinosaurs.

Land.description1Russian: Huayangosaurus existed in the middle of the Jurassic period, about 168.3 - 163.5 million years ago (Bathonian and Callovian stages). They were distributed on the territory of modern China, in the Sichuan province. At the moment, Huaynosaurs are the earliest representatives of stegosaurs. They lived about 15 million years earlier than their most famous North American relative, the Stegosaurus. This supports the theory of the Asiatic origin of the entire order.
Land.description2Russian:
Huayangosaurus walked on four thick legs, and the hind legs were somewhat longer than the front ones. Although it did not have outstanding running qualities, it was generally somewhat more agile than its larger cousin, the Stegosaurus. Differs in a relatively massive and short skull. Such an unusual head with a wide base gives rise to some associations associated with early ankylosaurs. The premaxillary bone of the Huayangosaurus is equipped with teeth.
    We should also pay special attention to the unusual plates of the Huayangosaurus, stretching in two rows from the neck to the end of the tail. They differ significantly from the tall, spacious plates of the original stegosaurus or from the spiked back of a Kentrosaurus. We see small structures with jagged contours. This is evidence of an early stage in the development of the element. Depending on the place on the back, their shape also differs.

Land.description1Russian: Hypacrosaurus is a herbivorous dinosaur similar to Corytosaurus that lived in North America in the Cretaceous period 75 - 67 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
The first fossilized remains were found in 1910 by Barnum Brown near the Red Deer River in Alberta, Canada. The remains consisted of a partial skeleton without a skull, which Brown described in 1913 as Hypacrosaurus altispinus - similar to a tall lizard, believed to be closely related to the Saurolophus.
     The hypacrosaurus was 9 meters (30 feet) long and could weigh up to 4 tons. The crest resembles the crest of a Corytosaurus, but differs from it in that it is not so tall and tapers more sharply towards the top, has a wider base and a slight outgrowth at the back. Interestingly, the airways do not form an S-shaped ridge (at least in Hypacrosaurus altispinus), unlike other lambeosaurines. The dorsal spinous processes protruding from the upper part of the vertebrae are 5-7 times higher than their height, which gave the hypacrosaurus a high back in profile. Like most hadrosaurids, its skeleton is otherwise unremarkable, although some details of the pelvic bone are distinctive. Like other hadrosaurids, it was a bipedal or quadruped herbivore. Two known species, Hypacrosaurus altispinus and Hypacrosaurus stebingeri, are not differentiated by the typical method of unique characteristics, as Hypacrosaurus stebingeri has been described as transitional between the earlier lambeosaurines and the later Hypacrosaurus. An examination of the skull of an adult Hypacrosaurus stebingeri reveals an animal that is very similar to Hypacrosaurus altispinus.

Honoring Gordon's contribution
Land.description1Russian:
Genus was described by Thomas Huxley in 1859. He named the raptor Hyperodapedon gordoni after Dr. Gordon's contributions to Elgin County.
    Huxley discovered many semi-cylindrical teeth. Huxley distinguished Hyperodapedon from other rhynchosaurs only in the dentition. Later, Richard Lydecker found out that hyperodapedon has two rows of teeth on both jaws.
Land.description2Russian:
Hyperodapedon was a sturdy, stocky animal about 1.3 meters (4.3 feet) long. Apart from its beak, it had several rows of heavy teeth on each side of the upper jaw and one row on each side of the lower jaw, creating a powerful cutting action when eating. It is believed to be herbivore, feeding mainly on seed ferns, and became extinct when these plants became extinct in the late Triassic. The diagnosis of Hyperodapedon is based on many cranial and postcranial features, which include a basipterygoid process longer than a wide, ridge-shaped upper jaw near the main longitudinal furrow, deep notches of neural arches on the middle dorsal vertebrae, and a long scapula. blade, pronounced deltoid-pectoral ridge and proximal end of the humerus, wider at the distal end. The maxillary teeth plates are clearly visible in Hyperodapedon, and there are seven cranial, six postcranial, and three signs of synapomorphic teeth.
     Hyperdapedon is known from several species and was discovered in many parts of the world in connection with the unification of continents in the supercontinent Pangea during the Triassic period. Fossils of various species have been found in Argentina, Brazil, India, Scotland, Tanzania, Zimbabwe, and possibly Canada and Wyoming (USA).

Iguana tooth
Land.description1Russian: For the first time, the remains of this lizard were accidentally found by Mary Ann Manthem while walking. It happened in 1822 in England, later the remains of an iguanodon were found in a coal mine in Belgium.
Land.description2Russian:
The iguanodon is characterized by its beak and spiked opposing toes on the forelimbs. He had short fingers that could easily bend inward, they could grab tree branches) and three flat fingers covered with a stratum corneum and bending outward.
    Iguanodon got its name in 1825 from the English geologist Gideon Mantell, who found fossils, now classified as the fossil remains of the terasaurus ruen and mantellodon ruen. As a result, the iguanodon became the second dinosaur after the megalosaurus, which was named after the analysis of fossils. In addition, along with Megalosaurus and Hyleosaurus, he was the first to be called a dinosaur. The genus is part of a larger group called the iguanodonts. The taxonomy of the genus still raises numerous questions: throughout the history of the study, more and more species were attributed to it, and some species were subsequently reckoned to other genera.
     As scientists found more and more fossils that are the remains of the iguanodon, information about the genus became more and more over time. Numerous specimens, including nearly complete skeletons found in two famous burials, have allowed paleontologists to understand many aspects of the animal's life: food, mode of movement, and social organization. Also, as one of the first dinosaurs discovered, the iguanodon has taken a small but rather prominent place in popular culture.
     As its name suggests, the iguanodon's teeth were similar to those of an iguana, but were large. Unlike their related hadrosaurs, iguanodons have changed teeth only once in their entire life. The upper jaw had 29 teeth on each side, the premaxilla had no teeth, and the lower jaw had 25 teeth. The large difference between the number of teeth on the jaws was explained by the fact that the teeth on the lower jaw were much wider than those on the upper. In addition, due to the deep rows of teeth and other anatomical features, it is believed that iguanodons had cheek-like formations that allowed them to hold food in their mouths.
    Iguanodons were large herbivorous dinosaurs that could move on both four and, presumably, two legs. Representatives of the only species that indisputably belongs to the genus of iguanodons, I. bernissartensis, had an average weight of about 3 tons and an average body length of up to 10 meters, with some individuals reaching 13 meters in length. They had large and narrow skulls, a beak made of keratin in the front of their jaw, followed by teeth similar to those of an iguana, but larger and more frequent.
     The forelimbs were about a quarter shorter than the hind ones and ended in five-fingered hands, the three central fingers on them were adapted for support. The thumbs had spikes that were supposedly used for protection. At the beginning of the 19th century, these thorns were considered horns and were placed by paleontologists on the nose of an animal, their true position was revealed later. The little fingers, in contrast to all other fingers, were long and flexible. The toes consisted of phalanges, organized according to the formula 2-3-3-2-4, that is, on the big toe there were 2 phalanges, on the index toe - 3, etc. On the hind legs, adapted for walking, but not for running, there were only three fingers. The spine and tail were supported by tendons. These tendons have developed throughout the life of the animal and could ossify over time.

Land.description1Russian: Incisivosaurus is an interesting oviraptor from Asia. The incisivosaurus was 0.8 meters long and weighed 2 kilograms. The incisivosaurus lived 135 million years ago in China.
Land.description2Russian: The most significant and highly unusual feature of this dinosaur is its apparent adaptation to a herbivorous or omnivorous lifestyle. It was named for its highly prominent front teeth, which show wear and tear commonly found in herbivorous dinosaurs. The incisivosaurus was a small dinosaur, about 1 meter long, with a 10 cm skull. Incisivosaurus is one of the smallest dinosaurs that has huge incisors. Teeth like those of today's rodents made it possible to feed on seeds, nuts, cones, etc. The incisivosaurus is at the base of the oviraptorosaur group, making it more primitive than the caudipteryx.

Land.description1Russian: Kentrosaurus is a genus of relatively small ornithischian stegosaurid dinosaurs from Africa that lived in the Jurassic period 155-150 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
The fossil remains were discovered during a 1909-1911 German expedition to Tanzania, Africa, organized by the Berlin Museum of Natural History. An expedition led by paleontologist and geologist Werner Janensch excavated the Tendaguru Formation, an analogue of the American Morrison Formation, during which the remains of the Giraffatitan, Dikreosaurus and Kentrosaurus were discovered. Fossils of a new stegosaurus were discovered in 1910 and described by paleontologist Edwin Hennig in 1915 as Kentrosaurus aethiopicus - a spiny lizard. During four field seasons, about 1200 bones of this dinosaur were collected, but most of them were lost during the Second World War, the remaining 350 bones are in the Berlin Museum of Natural History and at the University of Tübingen Karl Eberhard.
     The centrosaurus was about 4.5 meters (15 feet) long and weighed about 1 ton. He moved on four limbs, he had a small elongated head and a long tail, reaching half the length of the body. Bony plates ran along the back from the neck to the pelvis; they were less wide and more elongated than that of the stegosaurus. Closer to the pelvis of the centrosaurus, the plates smoothly turned into sharp spines that went in pairs at regular intervals up to the end of the tail. The length of these spines was up to 73 cm. The longest spine was found near the femur and was previously reconstructed as coming out of the thigh, but new research suggests that it was in the region of the lizard's shoulder. Studies by the German paleontologist Heinrich Mallison in 2011 contain calculations in which the speed of the tail impact could reach 144 km / h, while the average swing speed reached 72 km / h.

Land.description1Russian: The bones of this dinosaur were found in 2000 in the Middle Jurassic deposits of the Berezovsky quarry, 2 km south of the village of Nikolskoye, Sharypovo region, Krasnoyarsk region of Russia.
Land.description2Russian: Kilesk is a species of carnivorous dinosaur dinosaurs from the family of proceratosaurids, which lived 165 million years ago in the territory of the present Krasnoyarsk Territory (Russia). It is one of the oldest members of the family known to science. The structure of the jaws is similar to the Proceratosaurus from England, Guanlong from China, which is characterized by a sagittal nasal ridge (although it is not preserved in the Kilesk). In terms of anatomical characteristics, the kilesk is closer to the Proceratosaurus than to the guanlong. The element of the holotype of the upper jaw reaches about 29 cm. The upper jaw is elongated and relatively low, contains 17 alveoli from the fallen teeth, the 5th alveoli contains the only preserved tooth. Presumably, this is the largest representative of its family, reaching a length of 5-6 meters. It is a basal proceratosaurid and stands at the very base of the evolutionary tree of this family.
