Lizard Lambeau
Land.description1Russian: Lambeosaurus is a hadrosaurid that lived in North America during the Cretaceous Campanian age, 76-75 million years ago. Many remains found in Canada, the United States and Mexico were of this genus, but only two Canadian species are currently recognized as valid.
Land.description2Russian:
The most famous species of lambeosaurus, Lambeosaurus lambei, was very similar to Corytosaurus in all but the shape of the crest. Unlike the Corytosaurus ridge, the Lambeosaurus ridge was pushed forward, and the hollow nasal passages inside were in front of the ridge, positioned vertically. Lambiosaurus also differed from Corytosaurus in the absence of bifurcated nasal processes that make up part of the sides of the ridge, which is the only way to distinguish juveniles of the two genera from each other, since the ridges took their final forms at the end of adulthood.
     Lambiosaurus was similar to other hadrosauroids and could walk on both legs and four, as evidenced by footprints. Lambiosaurus had a long tail, reinforced with ossified tendons that gave it rigidity. The front legs had four toes, the second, third and fourth of which ended in hoof-like growths, however, presumably, the animal could use the front legs to support branches while eating. The first finger was free and could be used to manipulate objects. Each hind paw had only three central toes.
    The ridge shape was different for the two most famous species. In Lambeosaurus lambei, the adult male crest was ax-shaped, and somewhat shorter and more rounded in specimens identified as females. The ax blade protruded before the eyes, and the handle was a solid bone shaft protruding above the back of the skull. The ax blade consisted of two parts: the upper part was a thin bone kok that grew in individuals that had almost reached maturity, and in the lower part there were voids that were a continuation of the nasal passages. In Lambeosaurus magnicristatus, the handle was significantly shorter, and the blade was taller and wider. The crest of the best lambeosaur specimen found is damaged, and only its anterior half has survived.
      The Canadian lambeosaurus species were apparently similar in size to the Corytosaurus, and were about 9.4 m long. Scale prints are known for several specimens; one of them, now referred to as Lambeosaurus lambei, had thin skin with uniform polygonal scutes randomly distributed over the neck, trunk and tail. Similar scales on the neck, forelimb, and leg were also found on a specimen of Lambeosaurus magnicristatus.

Leaellyn's lizard
Land.description1Russian: Leaellynasaura  is a genus of small herbivorous ornithischian dinosaurs from the Albian stage of the Early Cretaceous (dated to between 118 and 110 million years ago), first discovered in Dinosaur Cove, Australia. The only known species is Leaellynasaura amicagraphica.
Land.description2Russian:
It was described in 1989, and named after Leaellyn Rich, the daughter of the Australian palaeontologist couple Tom Rich and Patricia Vickers-Rich who discovered it. The specific name, amicagraphica, translates to friend writing and honours both the Friends of the Museum of Victoria and the National Geographic Society for their support of Australian paleontology.
     Leaellynasaura was an Australian polar dinosaur. At this period in time, Victoria would have been within the Antarctic Circle. Although this latitude is very cold today, it was significantly warmer during the mid-Cretaceous. Because of the Earth's tilt, Leaellynasaura and its contemporaries would still have been living under conditions with extended periods of both daylight and night. Depending on latitude, it is possible that the sun might not have risen for several weeks or months in the winter, which means that Leaellynasaura would have had to live in the dark for perhaps months at a time. A skull fragment interpreted as being from Leaellynasaura has been reported as showing enlarged eyes and the suggestion of proportionally large optic lobes, implying an adaptation to low-light conditions.
     However, the relatively large orbits of this specimen were more recently interpreted as representing characteristically large eyes of a juvenile individual,[5] rather than any low-light adaptation.

Lotus lizard
Land.description1Russian: Lotosaurus was 1.5 to 2.5 m (4.9 to 8.2 ft) long and a strongly built tetrapod. It was a herbivore that cut off the leaves with its toothless, beak jaws. The Lotosaurus, like some other Poposaurids, had a sail on its back, giving it an appearance similar in appearance to Permian pelicosaurs such as Dimetrodon and Edaphosaurus, although not as tall.
Land.description2Russian:
The lotosaurus lived on the edge of the South China Craton, the protomaterkus, which will push against the North China Craton and become part of Lavrzaia. The collision occurred around the time the residents of the Lotosaur Site were alive. Because of this, it is impossible to determine whether the lotosaurus was endemic to southern China, or emigrated from the northern one. Since its cousins from the ctenosauriskids and shuosaurids lived in different parts of Pangea at the same time, the latter theory looks more likely. The microfossils of the site indicate a tropical climate with pronounced dry and wet seasons. The bed was located in the floodplain of a hand or a stream.
    Since all the animals died almost at the same time, and the remains were in good condition, scientists suggested that the animals fell victim to drought or disease, and their remains were covered with silt. 
    The diet of the lotosaurus is unclear. On the one hand, it was a herbivorous animal, and given the alternation of seasons, the beak could serve to bite off the stems of hard or dry plants in the dry season. However, lotosaurs lived near rivers where the vegetation was softer. In addition, the close relatives of this pseudosuchus were almost without exception predators, so that part of its diet could have been meat. And if we take into account that the lotosaurus could be a semi-aquatic inhabitant, then the beak could also serve to split the shells of mollusks. The jaw shape is suitable for both plant and omnivorous diets. By opening bivalve shells, the lotosaurus could easily suck or lick soft shellfish meat.

Good mother
Land.description1Russian: The name of this large, non-aggressive herbivorous lizard means lizard is a good mother. This name was given to the Maiazaurus because, judging by the results of the research, the Maiazaur parents took great care of their cubs until they were large enough to leave the nest.
Land.description2Russian:
Paleontologists have been able to collect a lot of information about how the Mayasaurs raised their young. For example, the Mayasaurs are known to build nests from sand and mud. Each nest was in the shape of a vessel almost as tall as a person and about two meters in diameter - almost like a double bed, only round. The mother Maiasaur covered the nest with soft vegetation and laid eggs in it - on average, up to twenty.
    In the daytime, the sun's rays warmed the nest; thanks to the sand, this heat was retained at night. In addition, the temperature was maintained by the heat generated by the rotting plants. At night, the Mayasaur mother could curl up around her nest. The hatched cubs were only 35 centimeters long - they could even fit in a washing basin, but by the age of two months they became about twice as large.
     Maiazaurus mothers took good care of their young, and they did not have to find their own food on their own. They stayed in the nest, safe, while the mothers (possibly the fathers) gathered leaves and other vegetation for them. The Mayazavrav parents had enough worries. In order to feed themselves and their young, they had to collect a huge amount of plant foods every day, equal to the weight of a modern adult. The adult Maiasaur apparently chewed and swallowed food where it found it.
    Returning to the nest, she could regurgitate this mass, and the cubs ate what the parents brought. Some species of modern birds also feed their young in this way. But such tender care for offspring was not devoid of flaws. If Mayazaar parents went to dinner with a predatory dinosaur or died for any other reason, their cubs also died, because they could not yet take care of themselves on their own. In this case, they became easy prey for any small theropod.

From Minmi Pass
Land.description1Russian: Minmi was a small ankylosaur, reaching about 2 metres in length and 1 metre in height. It had long legs (for an Ankylosaur), with hind legs larger than the front legs.Minmi probably moved relatively slowly on four legs, based on its estimated mass and its leg length as determined by scientists from fossilized tracks.Its neck was short and its skull wide with a small brain.
Land.description2Russian:
Minmi was a small armoured dinosaur, classified in Ankylosauria (too primitive to be included in either the Ankylosauridae or Nodosauridae), that was quadrupedal and had a long tail. As with other ankylosaurians, Minmi was herbivorous. Unlike most herbivorous dinosaurs, there is direct evidence of the diet of Minmi: gut contents are known from the well-preserved nearly complete Minmi sp. specimen, found in the abdominal cavity in front of the left ilium. The gut contents consist of fragments of fibrous or vascular plant tissue, fruiting bodies, spherical seeds, and vesicular tissue (possibly from fern sporangia). The most common remains are the fibrous or vascular fragments, which are typically rather uniform in size at 0.6 to 2.7 millimetres (0.02 to 0.11 in) long and have clean cuts at their ends, perpendicular to a given fragment's long axis. Because of the small size of the fragments, they have been interpreted as having been nibbled from plants or chopped in the mouth, evidence of some method of retaining food in the mouth. These small fragments may have come from twigs or stems, but their size is more suggestive of vascular bundles in leaves.
   The clean cuts and lack of gastroliths suggest that the animal relied on oral processing instead of gastroliths or grit to grind food. The seeds  and fruiting bodies  were apparently swallowed whole. Comparison to gut contents and scat from modern herbivorous lizard, emu, and goose indicates that this Minmi individual had a more sophisticated process for cutting up plant material.It had bony protrusions, also known as body armour, on its head, back, abdomen, legs and along the tail. Several types of armour are known in place in Minmi sp., including small ossicles, small keeled scutes on the body, large scutes without keels on the snout, large keeled scutes on the neck, shoulders, and possibly tail, spike-like scutes on the hips, and a combination of ridged and keeled scutes and triangular plates on the tail. There was one preserved ring of scutes around the neck. The arrangement of armour is unclear on the tail, although the triangular plates may have run on the sides of the tail, with long scutes forming a row along the top of the tail.However, unlike other ankylosaurians, Minmi had horizontal plates of bones that ran along the sides of its vertebrae (hence its species name, M. paravertebra).

Mouse lizard
Land.description1Russian: Mussaurs lived on Earth during the Triassic period and were therefore one of the earliest dinosaur species. They were first identified by a skeleton found in South America, one of the smallest dinosaur cubs ever encountered by paleontologists.
Land.description2Russian:
Mussaurs belonged to typical prozauropods: they had a small head, long neck, massive body and long tail; the hind legs are larger than the front; on each foot - five fingers. Like all prozauropods, mussaurs had many small leaf-shaped teeth in their mouths with which they processed their plant food.
  The teeth were probably only used to tear the plant into pieces small enough to be swallowed. Prozauropods did not chew food with their teeth; they ground it already in the stomach thanks to the small pebbles they had crushed, otherwise they are called touring. Predators did not need to improve their digestion in this way.

Swan-titanium
Land.description1Russian: Olorotitan is the most complete specimen of lambeosaurines found outside North America. This dinosaur was one of the largest members of its family, such as Parasaurolophus, reaching 8 meters (26 feet) in length. It is characterized by hadrosaurid-specific features, the most obvious of which is the unique ridge crowning the skull.
Land.description2Russian:
The fossils of this dinosaur were found in the Kundur bone-bearing deposit, which was discovered in 1990 by geologist Vladimir Nagorny in the vicinity of the village of Kundur, Arkharinsky district of the Amur region, during the construction of a section of the Chita-Khabarovsk road of the Moscow-Vladivostok federal highway. Then the builders working on the spot noticed the bones that came across, but they were sure that these were the remains of bears. Large-scale scientific research began in 1998 under the guidance of Yuri Bolotsky, Candidate of Geological and Mineralogical Sciences. Even then, the son of the scientist, Ivan, took part in the excavations, who initiated the main discovery - he discovered the first four caudal vertebrae of Olorotitan.
    During the first summer, a tail of 75 vertebrae and the back of a raptor's body were found at the Kundur deposit. Excavations in the Arkharinsky region were carried out for three years. The biggest intrigue for paleontologists was whether a dinosaur head could be found. He really turned out to be a bastard: there is no way to lie down along the track, but he fell perpendicularly. If the tail was on the surface, then the whole body was in the thickness, and above it four meters of soil. In addition, it was lined with isolated bones, since it lay down like a dam in the path of a mud-stone stream, and there were bones of other creatures on it, - says Yuri Leonidovich.
     In 1999, paleontologist Pascal Godefroy from the Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences joined the excavations, and in 2000 - employees of the Paleontological Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences from Moscow. The expedition was crowned with triumph: for the first time in Russia, a whole skeleton of one individual, including the skull, was discovered near Kundur. The extraction of bones from the breed lasted three field seasons from 1999 to 2001, and in 2003 this find was described by paleontologists Pascal Godefroy, Bolotsky and Alifanov under the name Olorotitan arharensis - titanium swan. In 2012, they published an osteological study of the anatomy of the skeleton and its individual bones.
     The holotype (AEHM 2/845) consists of a well-preserved skeleton with an incomplete skull. Although most of the bones of the skull were slightly displaced, and the bones of the nose were not completely preserved, the skull was reconstructed quite accurately. The find is the first nearly complete naturally articulated dinosaur skeleton found in the Russian Far East. A reconstructed skeleton of this dinosaur is on display at the Museum of the Royal Institute of Natural Sciences in Brussels, Belgium.

Robbing birds
Land.description1Russian: Ornitholesteses were small, carnivorous, gregarious dinosaurs; they probably ate mainly carrion. In addition, insects and other small animals, including possibly early bird species, were included in their diet. They could also eat eggs, which is hinted at by their name, literally meaning robbing birds.
Land.description2Russian:
Ornitholesteses were a type of dinosaur that lived in the late Jurassic period in the part of the planet that is now called North America. They lived about 150 million years ago. Ornitholesteses were rather small dinosaurs and weighed extremely little. The body length of an adult arnitolest is from tip of nose to tiptail - no more than 2 meters.
     The thigh of the coeluresaurus consisted of three bones, each of which extended in a different direction than the other two. Therefore, scientists call them Zavrishians, which means having hips like lizards. Their pelvis is the same as that of modern crocodiles, and the pubic bone protrudes downward and forward as seen in this illustration. In another variety of dinosaurs - Nitischians, or having hips, like in birds, these two bones are parallel, that is, directed in one direction. No one can pinpoint the exact reason for such a sharp difference in the structure of the hip for different types of dinosaurs.
     The hands of the forelimbs also had their own distinctive features: each had two very long clawed fingers of approximately the same length and one shorter, opposing finger, which could bend inward just like a human thumb. This finger is very useful when the ornitholes capture prey. Arnitoleste had more teeth than other coelurosaurs, and its bite was probably more powerful. His lower jaw was extremely strong and deep. The flexible neck allowed the ornitholest to easily grab a small prey, which he killed, thrusting razor-sharp teeth into it. But Ornitholestes himself could sometimes become a victim a larger predator, a hunter for easy prey. Some scientists believe that, due to its small size, Ornitholestes could sometimes feed on the remains of a meal of larger predators, prowling under their feet and remaining unnoticed.

Brave lizard
Land.description1Russian: The most notable feature of the Uranosaurus is the large sail on its back, supported by long spinous processes that spanned the entire rump and tail and resembled the predatory Spinosaurus that lived at the same time.
Land.description2Russian:
Uranosaurus was a fairly large dinosaur. Early estimates in 1976 were 7 meters (23 feet) in length and 4 tons in weight. Gregory S. Paul in 2010 estimated the length at 8.3 meters (27 feet) and 2.2 tons in weight, highlighting that the animal was relatively easy to build. The Uranosaurus had a skull that was 67 centimeters long. The head was very elongated and flat, much longer than that of the Iguanodon. The muzzle was toothless and covered with a cornea during life, forming a very wide beak. Behind the beak, there were large batteries of cheek teeth, and they also ran along the sides of the jaws: twenty-two teeth in both the lower and upper jaw, for a total of eighty-eight.
     The first four dorsal vertebrae are unknown, the fifth reaches 32 centimeters in length, the tenth, eleventh and twelfth are the longest, about 63 centimeters. The outgrowths on the six sacral vertebrae are noticeably lower and gradually taper towards the end of the tail. The dorsal sail is usually explained as either a system for thermoregulation or a hump structure of muscle or fat, reminiscent of a camel or elk. The forelegs were rather long. (55% of the length of the hind legs). On each hand, the thumb formed a thorn that was much smaller than that of the Iguanodon. The second and third toes were wide and formed a hoof suitable for walking. The hind legs were large and strong, adapted to support body weight in a bipedal position.

Egg thief
Land.description1Russian: Oviraptors were one of the first dinosaurs to have boils, one of the signs that dinosaurs are the ancestors of birds.
Land.description2Russian:
Oviraptor was a small theropod, about 2 meters in length. It is traditionally depicted with a distinctive crest, like a cassowary. However, re-examination of the oviraptorids reveals that these high-crested species actually belong to the genus Kitipati, a relative of the oviraptor. The crest of the oviraptor itself is somewhat smaller than that of its large relative. In 2010, Gregory Paul estimated its dimensions at 1.6 meters in length and weight at 22 kg. It is sometimes mentioned that the oviraptor grew up to 2.5 meters, but again, this is the result of the Kitipati confusion.
     The distinctive features of the oviraptor are unknown, since most of the body is missing, and the fragments found are damaged. If you imagine it as an ordinary oviraptorid, then the oviraptor had strong legs, and a short and thick tail supported the body when walking. The arms were long - 20 cm in length.
    The skull is only 20 cm long. The crest is small, but its exact structure cannot be restored, since the specimen is crushed, and the nasal bones have not preserved the upper part. Given its flat nostrils, the ridge cannot be very large, however the slope of the frontal bones indicates that it was higher than the occiput.
     The neck is long, the skull has large holes. No real teeth. Oviraptorids have a beak. In the oviraptor, it was short, carrying 2 small projections on the curved upper jaw. Oviraptor used them to crack clam shells and possibly nuts. He could also grab lizards and invertebrates with them. According to some paleontologists, the oviraptor could hit the victim with its beak like a hammer.
     Oviraptor had a fan of feathers on the tail, like a peacock, and also a kind of semblance of wings from flight feathers in his hands. Feathers covered the bodies of all oviraptorosaurs.
     However, the remains of feathers or related structures were not found in oviraptor, but in other oviraptorosaurs, such as the caudipteryx. It is also worth considering that the structure of the body of an oviraptor assumes not only the presence of feathers, but also warm-bloodedness. On the ribs were small hook-like processes that served to drive the posterior respiratory sacs, which, during breathing, first draw in air and then push it into the lungs to provide fresh air necessary for high metabolism. This feature has been preserved in modern birds.

Land.description1Russian: Pachycephalosaurus is a fat-headed herbivorous dinosaur that lived in the Upper Cretaceous in the territory of the modern USA and Canada.
Land.description2Russian:
Like its other relatives, the pachycephalosaurus was a bipedal animal with a body length of about 4.5 meters (15 feet) and a mass of about 1 ton. At the top of the skull was a large dome, up to 25 cm high, which reliably protected his brain. The back of the dome was bordered by a bony rim of short spines and horns, lengthening at the top. The large, rounded eye sockets located in the front suggest that the animal had good binocular vision. The small muzzle ended in a pointed nose, the teeth were tiny, with leaf-shaped crowns.
     In 2007, at the annual meeting of the Society of Vertebrate Paleontology, it was announced that Dracorex and Stygimoloch may be juvenile specimens of a pachycephalosaurus. Jack Horner of Montana State University presented evidence based on the skull analysis of a Dracorex specimen, indicating that this dinosaur may well be a young form of Stygimolochus. In addition, he presented data that indicate that Stygimoloch and Dracorex may be juvenile forms of Pachycephalosaurus. Horner and Goodwin published their findings in 2009, showing that the spines on the dome of the skull show extreme similarity between all three species, moreover, Dracorex and Stygimoloch are only known from juvenile specimens, while the Pachycephalosaurus specimen is an adult. These observations are complemented by the fact that all three forms lived at the same time and in one place. The discovery of pachycephalosaurus baby skulls, which were described in 2016 from two different locations in the Hell Creek formation, provided further evidence for this hypothesis. The fossils described by David Evans and Mark Goodwin are identical to all three alleged genera.

Land.description1Russian: Parasaurolophus was a hadrosaurid, part of a diverse family of Cretaceous dinosaurs known for their range of bizarre head adornments. This genus is known for its large, elaborate cranial crest, which at its largest forms a long curved tube projecting upwards and back from the skull. Charonosaurus from China, which may have been its closest relative, had a similar skull and potentially a similar crest. Visual recognition of both species and sex, acoustic resonance, and thermoregulation have been proposed as functional explanations for the crest. It is one of the rarer hadrosaurids, known from only a handful of good specimens.
Land.description2Russian:
Like most dinosaurs, the skeleton of Parasaurolophus is incompletely known. The length of the type specimen of P. walkeri is estimated at 9.5 m (31 ft), and its weight is estimated at 2.5 tonnes (2.8 short tons). Its skull is about 1.6 m (5 ft 3 in) long, including the crest, whereas the type skull of P. tubicen is over 2 m (6 ft 7 in) long, indicating a larger animal. Its single known forelimb was relatively short for a hadrosaurid, with a short but wide shoulder blade. The thighbone measures 103 cm (41 in) long in P. walkeri and is robust for its length when compared to other hadrosaurids.The upper arm and pelvic bones were also heavily built. Like other hadrosaurids, it was able to walk on either two legs or four. It probably preferred to forage for food on four legs, but ran on two. The neural spines of the vertebrae were tall, as was common in lambeosaurines;  tallest over the hips, they increased the height of the back. Skin impressions are known for P. walkeri, showing uniform tubercle-like scales but no larger structures.
    The most noticeable feature was the cranial crest, which protruded from the rear of the head and was made up of the premaxilla and nasal bones. William Parks, who named the genus, hypothesized that a ligament ran from the crest to the notch to support the head, and cited the presence of a possibly pathological notch as evidence.Although this idea seems unlikely, Parasaurolophus is sometimes restored with a skin flap from the crest to the neck. The crest was hollow, with distinct tubes leading from each nostril to the end of the crest before reversing direction and heading back down the crest and into the skull. The tubes were simplest in P. walkeri, and more complex in P. tubicen, where some tubes were blind and others met and separated. While P. walkeri and P. tubicen had long crests with only slight curvature, P. cyrtocristatus had a short crest with a more circular profile.

Land.description1Russian: Postosuchus is a large ravisuchid that lived 227-210 million years ago in Texas and Arizona (USA).
Land.description2Russian:
Postosuchus was one of the largest carnivorous reptiles in the late Triassic. Adults reached about 1.2 m (3.9 ft) in height, 4 m (13 ft) in length from nose to tip of tail, and their weights could range from 250 to 300 kg (550 to 660 lb). He had a massive skull with dagger teeth. The neck was elongated, passing into a short torso and a long tail. Along with skeletal remains, paleontologists also identify osteoderms, which were thick plates that formed scales. They were on his back, neck, and possibly above or below his tail.
     The neck of the Postosuchus consists of at least eight cervical vertebrae, followed by sixteen dorsal vertebrae, while four jointly ossified sacral vertebrae support the hips. It is believed that there are more than thirty vertebrae in the tail, decreasing in size towards the end. A pelvis with a hooked pubis and a rod-shaped ischium resembled the pelvis of a carnosaur dinosaur. The Postosuchus ribcage had the typical archosaur structure of large, thin, curved ribs. Some discoveries have found ribs associated with gastralia, skin bones located in the ventral portion of the body.
     The limbs were located under the body, which gave the postosuch a straight stance. Historically, there has been controversy over whether Ravisuchids like Postosuchus were primarily bipedal or quadruped. Each of the two forelimbs of Postosuchus was slightly more than half the size of the hind limbs. This feature of short forelimbs is usually seen in bipedal reptiles. Chatterjee theorized that Postosuchus could walk in an upright position, since the short forelimbs were probably only used when moving slowly. In 1995, Robert Long and Philip A. Merry argued that Postosuchus was robustly built and four-legged. Peyer et al. 2008, argued that the thick chest girdle served to move the forelimbs. They noted that this, however, does not detract from the theory that Postosuchus could also walk on two legs. In 2013, a major study of skeletal structure concluded that Postosuchus may have been an obligate bipedal animal based on anatomical data from the fingers, vertebrae, and pelvis. The proportions of the limbs and supporting parts of the spine were very similar to that of many theropod dinosaurs, almost all of which are believed to be strictly bipedal.

before compsognath
Land.description1Russian: It is one of the smallest dinosaur species found to date. Michael Crichton made Procompsognathus one of the main Heroes of The Lost World, a sequel to Jurassic Park, where dinosaurs were reborn.
Land.description2Russian:
In the spring of 1909, while excavating a rubble quarry near the town of Heilbronn in Germany, paleontologists stumbled upon some very interesting fossil remains. They found not a whole skeleton, but pieces of a fractured skull, right shin, femur and other parts of the skeleton, irrefutably proving that the dinosaur found belonged to a new, previously unknown species. Moreover, the remains date back to the end of the Triassic period, when dinosaurs had just appeared. Later, the newly discovered species was given the name Procompsognathus, it is one of several unique species of dinosaurs found in this part of Europe.
  The skeletons of small dinosaurs, which weighed comparatively little, broke apart quite easily and quickly after the death of the dinosaur, while the bones of large dinosaurs remained largely intact. This is probably why so few small dinosaur remains have been found compared to the large number of larger prehistoric dinosaur skeletons found.
  It is possible that the lifespan of small dinosaurs was shorter than that of their large relatives. Many small dinosaurs could fall prey to huge carnivorous dinosaurs, being easy prey due to their small size.

Land.detailRussian:
Late Cretaceous period
0,6 meters (2 ft)
1,8 meters long (6 ft)
180 kg (400 lb)
1923 year,  Mongolia
First horn-faced
Land.description1Russian: The protoceratops species was fierce, although by the standards of dinosaurs it was medium-sized, like all herbivores, it ate only vegetation and fought only for the sake of self-defense. Looking at its fossilized remains, it can be said that it had a beak-like mouth and a large bony collar around its neck.
Land.description2Russian:
The protoceratops reached approximately 1.8 meters (6 feet) in length and 0.6 meters (2 feet) in height in the back. A fully adult specimen weighed about 180 kg (400 lb). Unlike later ceratopsians, it was much smaller, lacked well-developed horns, and retained more primitive features than its larger relatives. Protoceratops was a four-legged dinosaur that is characterized by a small collar at the back of the skull. The bony frill contained two holes in the frill, and on the cheeks there were large spines formed by the cheekbone. The skull ended in a massive beak. The exact size and shape of the skull frills varied from individual to individual, with some specimens being short, while others had frills nearly half the length of the skull. Peter Dodson et al. Researchers attribute the different sizes and shapes of these collars to the difference between male and female protoceratops. The large number of specimens found in high concentration suggests that the protoceratops were gregarious.
    The wide chest of the protoceratops contained a huge stomach, capable of digesting incredible amounts of plant food. The same structural features are observed in modern pigs, so a number of scientists believe that the lifestyle of the protoceratops was similar: they also rummaged in the ground in search of roots, tubers and other edible vegetation. Perhaps the type of behavior and lifestyle of the protoceratops was largely reminiscent of a modern pig. However, with grater-like teeth and a parrot-like beak, protoceratops could eat much coarser food. The teeth of the protoceratops were tightly closed together in long rows and formed several vertical columns. As the incisal teeth wore out, they fell out and were replaced underneath by new teeth. Thus, the Protoceratops has always had a set of powerful, excellent teeth in good condition to chew on coarse plant foods.

Early Cretaceous period

Parrot lizard
Land.description1Russian: The remains of this dinosaur were discovered in 1922 by an expedition of the American Museum of Natural History in the Gobi Desert, Mongolia. In 1923, Henry Fairfield Osborne, based on sample AMNH 6254, described the new species as Psittacosaurus mongoliensis - a parrot lizard, due to the similarity of its beak.
Land.description2Russian:
Psittacosaur species vary in size and features of the skull and skeleton, but have a common body shape. Psittacosaurus was a small bipedal dinosaur. The most famous species P. Mongolian can reach 2 meters (6.5 feet) in length. The maximum body weight of an adult was over 20 kg (44 lb). The largest species P. Siberian could reach a length of more than 2.5 meters. The Psittacosaurus was a primitive dinosaur that, like the more advanced ceratopsians, had a strongly curved beak similar to that of a parrot. The beak was covered with a rough cornea and was ideal for plucking leaves and stems of plants. The upper part of the beak consisted of a special bone called the rostrum, which is found only in this group of animals. Psittacosaurus had rudiments of a cervical collar formed by a small projection of bone at the base of the skull, as well as unusual protruding spines in the cheekbone region. The functions of these spines are not clear, but they are present in all horned dinosaurs. Psittacosaurs chewed food in a rather unusual way. They did not move their jaws up and down, like scissors, as other dinosaurs did, the lower jaw of a psittacosaur could only move forward and backward relative to the upper one, like the millstones of a mill, grinding food.
     The Psittacosaurus is the only ornithischian that most likely used gastroliths, although there is evidence that stegosaurs may have used this technique. Gastroliths have been found in the stomach area of some prozauropods, sauropods, and theropods. Scientists are confident that the stones found in the stomach of dinosaurs acted exactly as described, because many modern birds, such as chickens and ostriches, use gastroliths for the same purpose.

Ceratops with regalia
Land.description1Russian: Lived Regaliceratops about 68-70 million years ago (Cretaceous period) in the south of modern Canada. This five-meter dinosaur weighing 1.5 tons had a powerful bone collar and unusual corneous processes, for which the press dubbed it Hellboy (in honor of the hero of the same name in films and comics).
Land.description2Russian:
The only skull was discovered in 2005 by geologist Peter Heves on the Oldman River in Alberta, Canada. It took two seasons to extract the fossils and another 18 months to clean up in the lab. In 2015, Marshall Brown and Donald Henderson described the species Regaliceratops peterhewsi, a regalia (ornaments on the head) ceratopsian. The original specimen is in the Royal Tyrrell Museum in Drumheller, Canada.
     For self-defense, like most of the ceratopsians, three horns were used, located on the front of the skull. However, their sizes were fundamentally different: two small horns above the eyes and one large above the nose. All previously known fossils of horned lizards had the opposite configuration: a small horn on the nose and two large ones above the eye sockets. What caused this feature of the dinosaur, paleontologists do not yet reliably know. However, statements about the convergent course of evolution in this species are gaining increasing approval in scientific circles. The fact is that Regaliceratops was in many ways similar to another group of dinosaurs - centrosaurins, and there are many cases in history when one species, as it evolves, begins to acquire the features of other animals, and not necessarily related ones. Centrosaurines died out much earlier.

Land.description1Russian: Sinornithosaurus is a small feathered dinosaur from China that lived in the Cretaceous period 125-122 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
Sinornithosaurus was discovered in 1999 in Liaoning Province, China. It was described by Xu Xing of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing as Sinornithosaurus millenii, a Chinese pangolin bird. The second species, C. haoiana, was described in 2004, but a study by Mark Norell et al. (2012) found no significant differences from the type species C. millenii.
     The specimen of the synornithosaurus retains imprints of feathers that completely encircle the body and form wings. These feathers were indistinguishable in shape from those found on birds from the same geological deposits. Body feathers were generally between 3-4.5 cm long and included two types. The first type is formed from several threads and combines into bundles, similar to modern fluff. The second type, including on the hands, consisted of rows of threads connected to each other along the main shaft, which makes them similar in structure to the feathers of modern birds. However, unlike the feathers on the wings of flying birds, they do not have secondary branches that fly feathers do. It is speculated that the synornithosaurs could only glide from one tree to another.

Shandong Lizard
Land.description1Russian: Shantungosaurus - the largest representative of the herbivorous hadrosaurs, lived in China about 83-72 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
Shandungosaurus is one of the largest members of the ornithischian order, estimates published by Gregory Paul in 2010 put it at 15 meters for S. giganteus and 16.5 meters for Z. maximus.
    The elongated Shandungosaurus skull was enormous, probably about 1.63 meters. In front, it had a flattened shape resembling a duck's beak. The teeth in this place were completely absent, so this tool was used to pluck soft leaves and grass. A set of hundreds of tiny serrated teeth was arranged in rows closer to the base of the skull. This brush is designed for grinding soft to medium hard materials. The nostril openings are very wide and elongated, which may indicate the presence of elastic skin sacs. By inflating them when exhaling, the dinosaur could make loud sounds that could be the usual warning signals, as well as calls for partners during the mating season. The loud cries of a herd of Shandungosaurs could act intimidating to small and medium-sized predators that had come close. These dinosaurs had a very long, stiff tail that tapers from base to end. It was used as a counterweight and for balance when moving, because the weight of the animal was truly colossal for two-legged creatures. The base of the tail was wide, indicating adequate muscle volume. It was a good weapon against predators.
     Based on the structure of the jaws and teeth, we can conclude that Shandungosaurs ate soft plant food, chewing it thoroughly enough. In particular, leaves, shrubs, young branches and shoots, as well as needles were used. Therefore, their main home was the East Asian forests, full of goodies. Shandungosaurs were herd animals. This fact is confirmed by the finds of several individuals nearby. Their main enemies were the tyrannosaurids Tarbosaurus, which preferred to look out for very young or sick Shandungosaurs. Even they could only cope with an adult in a group.

Land.description1Russian: Shunosaurus is a genus of herbivorous dinosaurs from the Eusauropoda group, known from a number of fossils from the Middle Jurassic deposits of China (Dashanpu Formation).
Land.description2Russian:
The remains of at least 20 individuals of Shunosaurus are known, moreover, many are very well preserved, there are complete samples.
     The size of the animal was estimated by Gregory Paul at 9.5 meters, and the weight according to the same researcher was three tons.
      Shunosaurus was a fairly primitive sauropod.
     The animal's skull was shallow. The elongated jaws were slightly bent upward. Long teeth were in the form of flattened pegs, the crown made them look like a spoon. The limbs were long compared to the size of the body.
    The Shunosaurus neck consisted of 12 cervical vertebrae, the strongly curved processes of which were directed backward; the condyle of the atlas was poorly developed. Such a short neck was atypical for the axial skeleton of a sauropod and resembled that of a brachytrahelopan. Shunosaurus had 13 cervical and 4 sacral vertebrae; their peculiarity was in their structure: they were half empty and had many outgrowths, notable for their pronounced backward direction. It is strange that there was no large gap between the outgrowths on the back of the vertebra and the body of the next vertebra. The tail was longer than the rest of the body and consisted of 43 caudal vertebrae, crowned with a small bone club. It had two conical osteoderms.

6 meters (19,7 ft)
15 meters long (49 ft)
6 tons
1973 year,  Egypt
Spiked lizard
Land.description1Russian: Spinosaurus was one of the largest carnivorous dinosaurs known, possibly even longer than a Tyrannosaurus. Historically, the size of Spinosaurus has been compared to the largest theropods, reaching 12 meters in length. Estimates published in 2005 suggest that the pangolin could have grown even longer, 16-18 meters (41-55 feet) and weighed between 7 and 17 tons.
Land.description2Russian:
The skull of the Spinosaurus was long and narrow, with a sigmoid margin, similar to that of modern crocodiles. The narrow muzzle was filled with straight, tapered teeth - six or seven teeth on each premaxillus and twelve more on the jaw. The teeth did not have teeth, or they were at the base of the crowns. The second and third teeth on each side were noticeably larger than the others, creating a space between the small and large teeth in the anterior maxilla. The very tip of the muzzle, bearing several large front teeth, was widened, on the top of the skull, in front of the eyes, there may have been a small ridge. The nostrils were located near the eye sockets.
     The lower jaw is widened and raised in front, coinciding with the diastema on the upper jaw. The teeth are very long. Behind, the lower jaws narrow, become straight, and the teeth on them become very small. In total, there were 32 teeth on the lower jaw, 16 of them on the dentarium. The back part of the dentarium is higher, as it gradually passes to the complex part. Only the angular bone is known from it. The jaws indicate significant bite strength.
    The neural spines are very high and form a sail. Their length is more than 10 times the diameter of the vertebral bodies. Sails are not uncommon among extinct animals, however, unlike the pelicosaurs of Dimetrodon and Edaphosaurus, whose sails consisted of thin spines, in Spinosaurus, like Uranosaurus and Lotosaurus, sails consisted of thick, flat nerve spines. The dorsal sail of a spinosaurus, the tallest axial structure recorded among dinosaurs, is said to be either a thermoregulated surface, a muscle or fat hump, or simply a visual feature of the species. The neural spines grew up to 167 cm.
     The spinosaurus sail is unusual among dinosaurs for its function. While in Amargasaurus this structure served as a protective function, in spinosaurids the sail served for heating.
     Stromer believed that this structure served to support the hump of the camels. In support of this hypothesis, Jack Bailey argued that sail lizards had thicker nerve spines than pelicosaurs, and resembled in structure the nerve spines of mammals with fat humps.
     The rear of the sail is not exactly known due to lack of material. It is usually depicted as a simple semicircular arch. Some researchers suggest that the sail extended along the tail. However, a 2014 discovery shows that neural spines fell sharply in the pelvic region, and the cervical vertebrae did not have large enough spines, so the sail began in the shoulder area. The highest point of the sail was near the pelvis.

Land.description1Russian: The generic name of the dinosaur Stavricosaurus is associated with the name of the Southern Cross constellation (ancient Greek Σταυρός), depicted on the coat of arms of Brazil and clearly visible in the Southern Hemisphere, as evidence of rare dinosaur finds in the Southern Hemisphere. The specific name pricei is dedicated to the Brazilian paleontologist LI Price, who discovered the skeleton of a stavricosaurus.
Land.description2Russian: Stavricosaurus was a small and agile bipedal predator, reaching 2.25 meters (7.4 feet) in length, 80 centimeters (31 inches) in height and weighing 30 kg. It lived at the end of the Triassic period, 225 million years ago - making it one of the earliest known dinosaurs. Stavricosaurus is known from a partial skeleton consisting of most of the spine, legs, and lower jaw. The spine consists of 9-10 cervical, 15 dorsal, 2 sacral, and more than 40 caudal vertebrae. Stavricosaurus is considered to be more primitive than any other dinosaur, as it has only two sacral vertebrae, the elongation of the 3rd, 4th, and 5th cervical vertebrae, is also a primitive form. If we reconstruct the appearance of this dinosaur, then we can assume that its foot and hand had five fingers, which means they are at an early stage of evolution. The jawbone suggests that the head of Stavricosaurus was large, this detail indicates that it was a predator.

Roof lizard
Land.description1Russian: Stegosaurus - a large and rather strange-looking herbivorous dinosaur - was discovered in North America. The striking double row of plates along the ridge, turning into a spiny tail, for a long time puzzled paleontologists. They could not understand in any way what function these plates performed.
Land.description2Russian: The body length of the stegosaurus reached almost 9 meters, its legs were thick and short. Stegosaurus got its name, meaning roof lizard, because of the first impression of paleontologists, who believed that the plates on its back lay flat, like the tiles on the roof. However, to date, it has been found that these plates actually stood upright and could change their position. These plates formed a double row running along the back of the stegosaurus, and they were not positioned strictly opposite one another. The plates probably served as stabilizers for the stegosaurus' body temperature, preventing it from getting too high or too low. So, on a cold morning, a stegosaurus could expose its plates to the sun's rays so that they accumulate heat, like modern solar panels. At noon, the stegosaurus could turn these plates sideways so that the breeze cooled them slightly, lowering the body temperature.

Moloch from the river Styx
Land.description1Russian:
Stygimoloch is a genus of dinosaurs from the pachycephalosaurid family that lived in the Cretaceous period (70.6-66.0 million years ago) in the territory of the modern United States and Canada.
     The first fossils were discovered in 1957 in Chicago. A predator's tooth was found in the femur of the Stygimolochus, and the skull of Deinonychus was found next to the skeleton. Stygimoloch was herbivore. On his head was a bone dome with horns at the back.
Land.description2Russian:
Among North American pachycephalosaurus, only the pachycephalosaurus itself was larger. Unlike other pachycephalosaurids, the skull was relatively small, slightly laterally flattened, and pear-shaped. While the dome was reduced in size, the skull ornament was more intricate than any other pachycephalosaurus. Short, tapered horns covered the nose, and the back of the skull had an enormous pair of massive, backward-facing spines, up to 5 centimeters in diameter (2 inches) and 15 centimeters long (6 inches); they are surrounded by two or three smaller spines. The function of this unusual device is unknown.
   Even if other pachycephalosaurs have butted their heads (which is the subject of ongoing debate), the stygimoloch's small dome suggests this behavior was not that important. Instead, the skull ornament could have been used for display, defense, or perhaps all of this combined and used in battles like deer antlers. Another version is that the horns were used to attack the enemy's body.

Land.description1Russian: In September 1946, in the Mongolian Upper Cretaceous Nemegt deposits of the southern part of the Gobi Desert, the first of the Soviet paleontological expeditions of the USSR Academy of Sciences discovered the skull and a number of cervical vertebrae of a giant carnivorous dinosaur
Land.description2Russian: Tarbosaurus was one of the largest carnivores, comparable in size to a Tyrannosaurus. According to the original description in 1955, the Tarbosaurus measured 10 to 12 m (33 and 39 feet) in length. The mass of a fully adult individual is considered to be comparable to or slightly less than a Tyrannosaurus rex, estimated at about 4-5 tons. The largest known skull was about 1.3 m (4.3 ft) long, more than any other tyrannosaurid except the tyrannosaur itself. The skull was tall, like that of a Tyrannosaurus, but not as wide, especially towards the back. The narrower back of the skull meant that the Tarbosaurus' eyes were not focused directly forward, suggesting that it lacked the binocular vision of the Tyrannosaurus. Large holes in the skull reduced its weight somewhat. The number of teeth is 58 and 64 along the jaw, which is slightly more than in Tyrannosaurus, but less than in smaller Tyrannosaurids like Gorgosaurus and Alioram. Most of its teeth were oval in cross-section, although the teeth at the tip of the upper jaw had a D-shaped cross-section. This heterodontism is characteristic of the entire family. The longest teeth are in the upper jaw, with crowns up to 85 mm (3.3 in) long. The mandible had a ridge on the outer surface of the angular bone articulated with the posterior portion of the dentary, creating a unique locking mechanism for Tarbosaurus and Alioramus. Other tyrannosaurids did not have this ridge and had great flexibility in the lower jaw.

Late Cretaceous period
6 meters (20 ft)
9 meters long (30 ft)

1954 year,  Mongolia
Mowing lizard
Land.description1Russian: Therizinosaurus is a genus of giant therizinosaurids with huge claws that lived in the territory of modern Mongolia, inhabited at the end of the Cretaceous period 70 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
Although the Therizinosaurian fossils are very incomplete, inferences about their physical characteristics can be drawn based on the related Therizinosaurids. Like other members of their family, the Therizinosaurus probably had a small skull on a long neck, a bipedal gait, and a heavy, wide body (as evidenced by the wide pelvis of other Therizinosaurids). Has record-breaking forelimbs among dinosaurs, possibly reaching lengths up to 2.5 m (8.2 ft) or even 3.5 meters (11.5 ft) in the largest known specimen. The hind limbs terminated in four bearing toes, unlike other groups of theropods. In 2010, Gregory S. Paul estimated the maximum size of a Therizinosaurus to be 10 meters (33 feet) long and 5 tons in weight. The most distinctive feature of the Therizinosaurus was the presence of giant claws on each of the three toes of the forelimbs. Large specimens of claws are incomplete, but are likely to be about 1 meter (3.3 feet) long. These claws are the longest of any known animal.
     The claws were used as a defense by Therizinosaurus. It was not very necessary for him to bend branches to his mouth - there is a long neck for this - and they are great for fighting. But there is one problem with the blows of clawed paws - it is inconvenient to slap a tarbosaurus with them, as is often shown in popular culture. The claws are pointed at the ends and cannot be used as blades. Therizinosaurus delivered sharp, stabbing blows, trying to pierce the enemy. But to do this, you need to have good eyesight and coordination, which the Therizinosaurus retained from its carnivorous agile ancestors.
     Many of the bones of therizinosaurus look very similar to the bones of two other dinosaurs found in sediments of the same age in the same region of Mongolia. They are segnosaurus and erlicosaurus. All three of these dinosaurs were probably very close relatives. The well-preserved cherem of the Erlicosaurus has shed light on the Therizinosaurus' way of life. The skull of an Erlicosaurus was long, low, with a horny beak at the end. Small teeth with uneven edges indicate that the animal ate mainly plant foods, but sometimes it could diversify its diet with animal food in the form of small lizards and mammals. The Therizinosaurus had a similar diet, despite the powerful claws it used to harvest plants. Eating plants is rare among therapods, adding to the mystery of the study of this unusual animal.
      No fossil evidence of the Therizinosaurus having feathers has yet been found, however most modern scientists believe the Therizinosaurus had feathers, as evidence has been found that some Therizinosaurids (in particular, the Beipiaosaurus) had feathers.

Land.detailRussian:
Late Cretaceous period
3 meters (9,8 ft)
9 meters long (30 ft)

1887 year,  USA
Three-horned face
Land.description1Russian: Triceratops did not have to run away from danger: he could easily fight off an attacker in much the same way as modern rhinos do, lowering his head and rushing at the enemy. Thanks to its impressive horns, Triceratops could defeat even the most ferocious predators.
Land.description2Russian:
It is because of its horns - two above the eyes and one, smaller, on the nose - Triceratops got its name, meaning three-horned muzzle. The horns were very sharp and constituted a powerful weapon capable of causing even a Tyrannosaurus to flee. Some scholars believe that there were two or three species of Triceratops, since there are skeletons with different types of horns.
    Most dinosaurs had scales on their skin. In Triceratops, the hide appears to have been particularly thick. maybe scales formed on it a pattern resembling a mosaic tile. In addition, the Triceratops had sharp outgrowths on its cheeks and thick outgrowths all over its body. Note also the jagged edges of his bony collar.
    In 1994, the most complete skeleton of a Triceratops, nicknamed Raymond, was found, it is one of the most complete specimens of Triceratops. It is one of the most important specimens ever found, although only the right side of the skeleton is preserved, this fossil was the first specimen of Triseratops to be fully articulated, bones articulating in vivo and close to each other. This is very important for many reasons - this find helped answer scientists' questions about how Triceratops moved and what was the real structure of their legs. A replica of Raymond's skeleton is displayed high on the wall in the Black Hills Institute Museum. The original fossil was discovered in North Dakota, and the original is now in the National Science Museum of Tokyo, Japan. In 2002, in Wyoming, the remains of a Triceratops, nicknamed Lane, were found with large imprints of fragments of skin. This is the first discovery of a fossil specimen of Triceratops skin, making this finding very scientifically important. The fossils are at the Black Hills Geological Research Institute, Hill City.

Land.detailRussian:
Late Cretaceous period
0,6 meters (2,5 ft)
2 meters long (30 ft)
50 kg
1856 year,  Canada
Wounding tooth
Land.description1Russian: Troodon is a genus of small feathered theropod dinosaurs of the troodontid family that lived in the territory of modern North America at the end of the Cretaceous 70.6-66.043 million years ago.
Land.description2Russian:
The Troodon name was originally given by Joseph Leidy in 1856, based on a single tooth found in the sediment of the Judith River, Montana. From 1925 to 1945 it was considered a pachycephalosaurus due to the similarity of its teeth.
      Troodon was a small dinosaur measuring up to 2.4 meters (7.9 feet) in length, 0.9 m (3.0 feet) in height, and up to 50 kg (110 lb) in mass. Their eyes were very large (perhaps partially nocturnal), and turned slightly forward, giving the troodon some degree of depth perception. The teeth bear noticeable barbs similar to those of herbivorous reptiles, suggesting an omnivorous Troodon diet. This theropod had the largest brain of any dinosaur at the time, in terms of body weight (like modern birds). The lightweight skeleton and long legs made the Troodon an excellent runner.
     Troodon's teeth, strongly curved, flat, with sharp edges along the posterior edge, could very well cut the victim's flesh. The dinosaur had flexible hands, and the thumbs could move independently of the other two, so the hand turned into a strong grasping tool. In combination with a fast run, these qualities allowed the troodon to successfully hunt small agile game, such as mammals and lizards.
      By comparing the size of the animal's brain with the size of the body, scientists get an idea of the intelligence of the animal. The relative size of the brain of the troodon makes it possible to compare it in terms of mental development with a parrot. It may not look convincing, but the parrot is considered an intelligent bird. Troodon has well-developed lobes of the brain responsible for vision, and the eyes were the animal's first hunting tool. Also, some other parts of the brain that control body movement and balance were enlarged in the predator, which confirms the opinion of the troodon as a good runner. The intelligence of the Troodons allowed them to coordinate actions with each other during the hunt, so the troodon flock could catch quite large game.

Land.description1Russian: The Tyrannosaurus Rex was one of the most ferocious predators that has ever lived on planet Earth. If you were next to him, you could barely reach his knee. What a terrible monster he was!
Land.description2Russian:
Like other members of its family, the Tyrannosaurus was a bipedal predator with a massive skull that was balanced by a long, heavy and stiff tail. Compared to the large and powerful hind limbs of this lizard, its front legs were quite small, but unusually powerful for their size, and had two clawed fingers. It is the largest species of its family, one of the largest representatives of theropods and one of the largest land-based predators in the history of the Earth. One of the largest specimens of a tyrannosaur named Sue during life reached about 12.3-12.8 meters, height to the thigh - 3.6 meters, and the mass of this individual, according to experts, during life reached about 8.4-9.5 tons. As the largest carnivore in its ecosystem, the tyrannosaurus was most likely an apex predator and hunted hadrosaurs, ceratopsians, and possibly even sauropods, although some researchers suggest that it ate primarily carrion. Moreover, the debate over whether the tyrannosaurus was a full-fledged hunter and apex predator or a scavenger was one of the most intense and protracted in the history of paleontology. Now most experts believe that Tyrannosaurus was an opportunistic predator - it could both hunt and feed on carrion.
     The neck of the tyrannosaurus, like that of other theropods, was S-shaped, but short and muscular, which allowed it to support its massive head. The forelimbs had only two clawed toes together with a small metacarpal bone, the vestige of a third toe. The hind limbs, in contrast, were the longest (in relation to the body) of all theropods. The spine is formed by 10 cervical, 12 thoracic, five sacral and about 40 caudal vertebrae. The tail was heavy and long, as it performed the function of a balancer, balancing the massive head and overweight body. To compensate for the incredible bulkiness of the animal, many of the bones of the skeleton were hollow, which reduced their weight, but did not greatly affect the strength.
     The largest complete tyrannosaurus skull ever found is about one and a half meters long. Large windows in the skull helped to reduce its weight and create the necessary space for muscle attachment, like all carnivorous dinosaurs. But in other respects, the skull of a tyrannosaur was very different from the skulls of large non-tyrannosaur theropods. Its rear part was very wide, but the snout was narrow, due to which the lizard possessed highly developed binocular vision. The skull bones were heavy. The nasal and some other bones were combined, which prevented anything from entering the space between them. They were pneumatized (airy, that is, there were paranasal sinuses in the skull, like other non-avian dinosaurs). This probably made the bones more flexible and lighter. These and some other properties, which contributed to the strengthening of the skull, belong to the tendency of tyrannosaurids to increase the bite force, which in these lizards with a huge advantage exceeded that of all theropod-netyrannosaurids. The end of the upper jaw was U-shaped (while in most non-tyrannosaurian predators it was V-shaped); This shape made it possible to increase the number of tissues and bones that a tyrannosaurus could pull out of the victim's body in one bite, and also increased the pressure exerted by the front teeth of the lizard.
     Tyrannosaurus rex has a well-pronounced heterodontism - the presence of several types of teeth, differing in shape and function. The teeth on the anterior side of the upper jaw are close-fitting, have a D-shaped cross-section, a chisel-shaped blade that reinforces ridges and bends inward. These features reduced the risk of tooth fracture while the tyrannosaurus bit and dragged the victim. Other teeth are stronger and more massive, in shape they are more like bananas than daggers, they are wider apart and also have reinforcing ridges. The teeth of the upper jaw are larger than the teeth of the lower (except for those that are in its back). The largest tooth found so far, together with the root, reached a height of 30 centimeters. This is the largest carnivorous dinosaur teeth ever found.

Land.description1Russian: Velociraptor is a maniraptor from Asia that lived in the Cretaceous period 75-71 million years ago. It is the second largest brain among dinosaurs, the troodon is in the first place. He was one of the most intelligent dinosaurs of that time.
Land.description2Russian:
The first remains of a large claw and skull (sample AMNH 6515) were found on August 11, 1923, during the Roy Chapman Andrews expedition to the Gobi Desert organized by the American Museum of Natural History.   
Velociraptor was a relatively small dinosaur measuring 2 meters (6.8 feet) in length 0.5 meters in height and weighing about 20 kg. The elongated skull was up to 25 cm long and was slightly curved upward. The upper and lower jaws had 26-28 teeth, spaced and bent back to capture and hold prey. Like most theropods, Velociraptors had four toes on their hind legs, one of which was underdeveloped and did not participate in walking. On the second toe, there was a large, strongly curved sickle-shaped claw, growing up to 6.5-7 cm in length (along the outer edge), which was previously considered their main weapon for killing and tearing victims. It was experimentally confirmed that these Velociraptor claws were used not as blades, but as hooks, piercing the trachea or cervical artery of victims. Velociraptor forelimbs consisted of three fingers, the first being the shortest and the second the longest.
    The flexibility of the tail of the Velociraptors was reduced by the bony outgrowths of the vertebrae at the top and ossified tendons at the bottom. Bony outgrowths stretched along from 4-10 vertebrae, which gave stability when cornering, especially when running at high speed. In September 2007, researchers found bump prints on the forearm of a velociraptor found in Mongolia. These irregularities, as on the wing bones of birds, show where the feather roots were attached, their presence in the Velociraptor indicates that it was also covered with feathers. According to one of the versions, the Velociraptor could well be warm-blooded, since a significant amount of energy was required for hunting. Modern animals, which have bodies covered with feathers or down, tend to be warm-blooded, since these covers serve as thermal insulation. However, the rate of bone growth in dromaeosaurids and some early birds indicates a more moderate metabolism compared to most modern warm-blooded mammals and birds.

Sweem.description1Swim: Ambulocet is a genus of ancient cetaceans, a transitional form between land and water representatives of the group. The remains are described from the Paleogene deposits of the Punjab province (Pakistan), the first remains were found in 1994. The genus was described in 1996.
Sweem.description2Swim:
Outwardly, the animal vaguely resembled a cross between a crocodile and a dolphin. Fur remained on the skin. Feet are webbed. The tail and limbs were well adapted for movement in the aquatic environment. The teeth are sharp, triangular in shape.
     Ambulocet inhabited estuaries, river banks and the sea coast. Most of the time he lay on the beach, basking in the sun. Hungry, the whale went into the water and, like modern crocodiles, hiding near its surface, waited for the victim that came to the watering hole.
      In the water, this whale moved by bending its back and tail in a vertical plane. On land, Ambulocetus, like modern crocodiles, moved awkwardly. The animals spent the night on the shore, not far from the water
     One of the most amazing adaptations of the ambulocet to the aquatic lifestyle was its hearing. Unlike terrestrial mammals, the ears of this whale could not perceive vibrations in the air, because the vibrations of the environment were transmitted to them through the bones of the skull. Therefore, on land, the ambulocet did not hear well: in order to catch the approach of the victim by the vibrations of the soil, he had to attach his lower jaw to the ground.
Little is known about the life cycle of Ambulocet. When it was time to give birth, females may have moved from the sea to the rivers. Here, whale calves grew up and then migrated to estuaries and coastal sea waters.

Sweem.description1Swim: Ammonites are a subclass of cephalopods, the first representatives of which appeared in the Devonian period, the latter became extinct at the end of the Cretaceous period during the Cretaceous-Paleogene mass extinction.
Sweem.description2Swim:
Remains of ammonoids are found on all continents. They are guiding fossils for the Late Paleozoic and Mesozoic eras; many zonal scales have been built on the basis of ammonoids.
      Ammonites are an excellent example of a leading fossil, dating from rock deposits in which a specific species or genus is found at specific geological time periods. The name ammonite, from which the scientific term is derived, was inspired by the spiral shape of their petrified shells, which somewhat resemble the swirling horns of a ram. Pliny the Elder, in 79 AD, according to the Julian calendar, called the fossils of these animals Ammonis cornua (horns of Amun), since the Egyptian god Amon was often depicted with the horns of a ram. The name of the genera of ammonites often ends with -ceras, which is the Greek (κέρας) analogue for the word horn.
Arising from the early nautiloids, ammonoid cephalopods first appeared in the Devonian, about 400 million years ago, and became extinct at the end of the Cretaceous,65 million years ago, along with the dinosaurs. The classification of ammonoids is partly based on the ornament and structure of the shell chambers. While almost all nautiloids exhibit soft, curved sutures, the ammonoid suture line (the intersection of the septum with the outer shell) has an undulating structure that forms a corrugated surface. Ammonites (subclass Ammonoidea) differ in the structure of their partitions - dividing walls that separate the inner chambers and in the nature of their seams at the joints of the outer shell wall.

Sweem.description1Swim: Belemnites are representatives of the order of extinct invertebrates of the class of cephalopods. Belemnites existed from the Triassic to the Cretaceous period, reaching their heyday in the Jurassic and Cretaceous periods.
Sweem.description2Swim:
Belemnites were an important food source for many Mesozoic marine creatures, both the adults and the planktonic juveniles, and likely played an important role in restructuring marine ecosystems after the Triassic–Jurassic extinction event. They may have laid between 100 and 1,000 eggs. Some species may have been adapted to speed and swam in the turbulent open ocean, whereas others resided in the calmer littoral zone (nearshore) and fed off the seafloor. The largest belemnite known, Megateuthis elliptica, had guards of 60 to 70 cm (24 to 28 in).
      Belemnites were coleoids, a group that includes squid and octopuses, and are often grouped into the superorder Belemnoidea, though the higher classification of cephalopods is volatile and there is no clear consensus how belemnites are related to modern coleoids. Guards can give information on the climate, habitat, and the carbon cycle of the ancient waters they inhabited. Guards have been found since antiquity and have become part of folklore.
Belemnites had 10 hooked arms of, more or less, equal length with suckers. The hooks were rarely larger than 5 mm (0.20 in), and increased in size towards the midsection of the arm, possibly because the midsection is where maximum power could be exerted when grabbing, or bigger hooks on the extremities of the arm increased the risk of losing the arm. Having two rows of hooks covering the entire breadth of the arm, a belemnite could have had between 100 and 800 hooks in total. Some hooks have a spur just above the base, but this may be a distortion from fossilization or preparation of the material. The chitinous hooks are subdivided into three sections: the base—which can be either flat or concave—the shaft—which projects either upward at an incline either straight or bent—and the uncinus—which can be hook- or sabre-like. Overall, they were fish-hook shaped, and probably only the uncinus was exposed.
      Different hook shapes were probably specialized for certain tasks, for example, a strongly hooked uncinus was designed to stab prey at a constant angle and force, and sink in deeper if the prey tried to move away from the belemnite. Hook shapes and forms vary species to species. In Chondroteuthis, large hooks were common near the mouth, and were either used for surrounding small prey or ramming into large prey; however, these large hooks were not present in a small specimen, indicating it was either a juvenile—and the development of different hooks coincided with a difference in prey selection—or the specimen was a female and the hooks were used by males for male-on-male combat or during copulation. In modern hook-bearing squid species, only matured males have hooks, indicating a reproductive purpose. It is possible the hooks, being analogous to suckers, could move.

Sweem.description1Swim: Dakosaurus is a genus of marine crocodylomorphs of the Late Jurassic-Early Cretaceous era. They belong to the so-called saltwater crocodiles - the Metriorhynchidae family. These are the only fully marine archosaurs. One of the few metriorhynchids adapted almost exclusively to hunting large prey.
Sweem.description2Swim:
They belong to the so-called saltwater crocodiles - the Metriorhynchidae family. These are the only fully marine archosaurs. One of the few metriorhynchids adapted almost exclusively to hunting large prey.
    The sizes are large (the skull is up to 1 meter long, the total length is up to 6 meters). The muzzle is short, rounded in front, the skull is high, the teeth are huge, few, zyphodontic (like those of carnivorous dinosaurs). The orbits are large, with a scleral ring. There is a preorbital window, probably containing a salt gland. From above, the preorbital window is covered with outgrowths of the skull.
      The limbs are converted to flippers, especially the front ones. The front flippers are much shorter than the rear ones. The end of the tail is curved downward and served as the basis for a caudal fin similar to that of ichthyosaurs. The carapace is reduced.
     By way of life, Dacosaurs (especially Dakosaurus andiniensis) could resemble killer whales. Interestingly, most species shared the sea with large pliosaurs. Perhaps the Dacosaurs were more scavengers. It is not known how saltwater crocodiles bred. Apparently, they had to lay eggs (the eggs of crocodiles are dressed in hard shells and there are no viviparous species among modern crocodiles). To do this, you need to go ashore. Perhaps it was this feature that limited their size (there are no giant species among the metriorhynchids) and ultimately led to the extinction of the group at the beginning of the Middle Cretaceous.

Sweem.description1Swim: Elasmosaurus is the famous large long-necked plesiosaur of the Late Cretaceous period that lived in the territory of modern North America about 80 million years ago.
Sweem.description2Swim: Elasmosaurus was about 10.3 meters (34 feet) long and its body size is determined by comparison with its close relative, Albertonectes. He had a streamlined body with fins on his limbs, a short tail, a small head, and an extremely long neck. To date, an incomplete holotype specimen, cataloged as ANSP 10081, is the only specimen of Elasmosaurus. It was exhibited at exhibitions for a long time, but now it is kept in a closet, along with other similar fragments. The found Elasmosaurus specimen consists of parts of the posterior part of the right jaw, two jaw fragments with teeth, 72 cervical vertebrae, including an atlas and an axis, 3 thoracic vertebrae, 6 posterior vertebrae, 4 sacral vertebrae and 18 caudal vertebrae. as well as fragments of ribs. Cope's image shows the thoracic and pelvic girdle of an Elasmosaurus, but these elements were lost by 1906. In 1986, a 3D reconstruction of the Elasmosaurus model was completed and it is now displayed at the Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences (since 2011 Drexel University Academy of Natural Sciences). This reconstruction was later copied by Triebold Paleontology Incorporated and these copies have been displayed in other museums. One of them reaches about 12.8 m (42 ft) in length.

Sweem.description1Swim: Haasiophis is an extinct genus of snakes with preserved hind limbs. Represented by one known species, Haasiophis terrasanctus. His remains were found in Palestine. It is one of three genera of Cenomanian snakes with hind limbs.
Sweem.description2Swim:
The skull is well preserved, although slightly compressed. The skull displays a combination of basal and advanced features. The premaxillary bone is small and has no teeth, while the rest of the jawbones contain 73-75 teeth. The preorbital regions of the skull, being small and thin, are similar to the preorbital regions of python snakes.
      Along with its sister genus Pachyrhachis, Haasiophis does not possess either a sacral rib or vertebrae. Also like Pachyrhachis there is no preserved indication of a connection between the vertebral column and the pelvic girdle. The pelvic girdle is partly obscured by overlaying bones reducing the detail which can be seen. Radiographs of the specimen reveal H. terrasanctus possessing a simple triradiate similar to that possessed by Pachyrhachis. Both femurs are preserved with the specimen, but the rest of the right leg is missing. The left zeugopodium, tarsus, tibia, and fibula are preserved though the tibia is disarticulated slightly. The foot is composed of three tarsal ossifications and five metatarsals. The tarsal ossifications do not show signs that the bones were connected to each other during life. Traces of two phalanges are discernible behind metatarsals two and three.

Sweem.description1Swim: Helicopryon is one of the most bizarre fish, the most famous representative of the Eugeneodont order, a class of cartilaginous fish. The family Agassizodontidae (Helicoprionidae) includes about 6 genera, distributed from the Early Carboniferous to the Late Permian of all continents. These fish are not sharks in the modern sense of the word, but representatives of primitive cartilaginous fish, close to the ancestors of chimeras and sharks.
Sweem.description2Swim:
The structure of the body remains unknown. A closely related genus of fading has no anal and pelvic fins; the caudal fin is semilunar, symmetrical. It is interesting that many eugeneodonts (and this group includes both edestids and helicoprionids), in addition to the dental spiral on the symphysis, also have rows of pressing teeth on the jaws. This combination of pelagic fish body shape and pressing teeth seems very strange. Therefore, the assumption that helicopryon plowed shellfish out of the seabed may be false. It is possible that helicopryon and related forms ate ammonites. In this case, the spiral made it possible, for example, to cut off the tentacles, and the jaw teeth to crush the shells. But, possibly, helicopryons fed on fish (the spiral inflicted serious wounds on the victim, and the rest of the teeth allowed them to eat thick-scale prey). There are suggestions that helicopryon ate squid, krill shrimp and other soft foods. Coils on the dental symphysis are known in acanthodia and sarcopterygia, but in no other fish the spiral is so developed (2-3 turns). Modern fish do not give us any example of such dental equipment.
      The dental spiral turned out to be a completely mysterious formation. Karpinsky suggested that the spiral was located on the nose of the fish. This opinion persisted in the literature for many years (for example, such a reconstruction is presented in the fundamental edition of Fundamentals of Paleontology, published in the 1960s).However, even in the 19th century, alternative hypotheses were proposed - for example, the spiral could be located on the front dorsal or on the caudal fin. There was an assumption that the spiral could be movable.
